Q: What is the Tax Increment Worksheet (TIW)?
A:
The Tax Increment Worksheet ( PC-202 ) calculates property tax amounts for the Tax Incremental Districts (TIDs) within a municipality. The TIW uses the overlying taxing jurisdiction's apportioned tax levies and the value increment within each taxing jurisdiction to determine their share of the tax increment. The total tax increment is distributed to the municipality's TIDs.
The Tax Increment Worksheet (
PC-202
) calculates property tax amounts for the Tax Incremental Districts (TIDs) within a municipality. The TIW uses the overlying taxing jurisdiction's apportioned tax levies and the value increment within each taxing jurisdiction to determine their share of the tax increment. The total tax increment is distributed to the municipality's TIDs.

Q: Who needs to file the TIW?
A:
Any town, village or city with one or more TIDs with a positive total value increment must complete the TIW each year. You must file this worksheet before you can file the Statement of Taxes (SOT).
Note: If your TID has a negative total value increment, you are not required to submit a TIW; however, you must still file an SOT.

Q: How do I file the TIW?
A:
You must electronically file the TIW. This form is located in My DOR Government Account . For more information, review our Online Filing Help – Using My DOR Government Account .
You must electronically file the TIW. This form is located in
My DOR Government Account
. For more information, review our
Online Filing Help – Using My DOR Government Account
.

Q: What is the deadline to file the TIW?
A:
Each required municipality must e-file the TIW with the Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) by the third Monday in December. Note: You must file the TIW before you complete the mill rate worksheet.
Each required municipality must e-file the TIW with the Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) by the third Monday in December.

You must file the TIW before you complete the mill rate worksheet.

Q: Where do my values come from for filing the TIW?
A:
Most values on the TIW are auto-filled. The only value you need to report is the municipality's local levy, which is the sum of these lines from the Statement of Taxes (SOT):
Note:
- Other special purpose district taxes ( Line C1)
- Other state special charges (Line C4)
- County special charges (Line C5)
- All other town, village or city taxes (Line C6)
- Do not include any tax increment in your municipality's local levy
- Special purpose districts are not authorized taxing jurisdictions; in result, you must include their levies in your municipality's local levy on the TIW

Q: What if an auto-filled apportioned levy is missing or incorrect?
A: You must contact the taxing jurisdiction directly and notify DOR's Local Government Services Bureau. Taxing jurisdictions (except schools) report their apportioned levies to DOR. School districts provide their apportioned levies to the Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction (DPI), which is shared with DOR.

Q: Which levy amount from the TIW should I use to calculate property tax mill rates – Column A (Apportioned Levy) or Column E (Levy Amount)?
A: Use Column E (Levy Amount) to calculate mill rates for property tax bills. This will ensure the total apportioned tax levies and the tax increment are collected. Column A (Apportioned Levy) amounts will be shown on your municipality's SOT. Column F's (Tax Increment) amount will appear on the SOT, Section C, Line 2.

Q: I found an error on my TIW; can I fix it?
A:
Yes. You can electronically amend Form PC-202 to correct your municipal levy entry, located on our website: https://www.revenue.wi.gov/Pages/OnlineServices/slfiling.aspx After you amend the TIW, you must also amend the SOT.
Yes. You can electronically amend Form PC-202 to correct your municipal levy entry, located on our website:
https://www.revenue.wi.gov/Pages/OnlineServices/slfiling.aspx
After you amend the TIW, you must also amend the SOT.

Q: What happens if I use the wrong levy from the TIW in my mill rate calculations?
A: Always use TIW, Column E levies for your mill rate calculations.  If you use the apportioned levies (Column A), you will not collect the tax increment for your TIF districts and may need to reissue property tax bills.

Q: Do I need to provide a copy of the TIW to the county?
A: You must provide your completed Tax Increment Worksheet to the county if the county is printing your tax bills.​

Q: What is the  telecommunications property tax?
A: Telephone companies are assessed as ad valorem property tax. Tax revenue  the Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) collects from telephone companies  goes to the state's general fund.

Q: How does the  telecommunications property tax affect local property taxes?
A:
- Telecommunication property is exempt from the local  property tax administered under Chapter 70 of the Wisconsin Statutes
- Non-telecommunication property that changes its use to  telecommunication is shifted from local property tax to the state  telecommunication property tax and vice-versa
Telecommunication property is exempt from the local  property tax administered under Chapter 70 of the Wisconsin Statutes
Non-telecommunication property that changes its use to  telecommunication is shifted from local property tax to the state  telecommunication property tax and vice-versa

Q: What is the  definition of telecommunication services?
A:
- Telecommunication service is defined as two-way  transmission of voice, video, facsimile or data messages, including telegraph  messages
- It does not include one-way transmission of cable  television, radio or paging equipment
- Examples of telecommunication companies: Local exchange  companies (LEC), competitive local exchange companies (CLEC), inter-exchange  companies (IXC), digital subscriber line companies (DSL) and commercial  mobile service companies (wireless)
- A Tower Company (owning and/or managing cell towers) is not a telecommunication company since a tower does not provide telecommunication services

Q: What  property is taxed and what property is not taxed?
A:
- Taxable property — includes real estate and personal property. Personal property - includes  outside plant (cable, wire and poles), central office (circuit and switch)  equipment, administrative office furniture and equipment, towers, antennae and  supplies.
- Non-taxable property — includes administrative computers and intangibles (ex: goodwill)
- “Qualified broadband service property" — means tangible personal property that meets the following standards: The property is installed in a rural area, and is used to provide Internet access service to the rural area at actual speeds that are at least a download speed of 25 megabits per second and an upload speed of 3 megabits per second
- The property is installed in a rural area, and is used to provide Internet access service to the rural area at actual speeds that are at least a download speed of 25 megabits per second and an upload speed of 3 megabits per second

Q: How is telecommunication  property assessed and how is the tax rate calculated?
A:
- Property  assessed — DOR assesses the property in the same manner  as manufacturing property. DOR staff assesses manufacturing and  telecommunication property under the same statutory standards that apply to the  commercial and residential property assessments. A telecommunication company  must file annual self-reporting forms for its property. DOR audits the property  every five years.
- Tax rate  calculated — the tax rate for a telecommunication property  is the sum of the net property tax rates (after credits) from the prior year in  the taxing jurisdictions where the property is located

Q: Will my data be encrypted or otherwise protected when it's transmitted over the Internet?
A: Yes. Your data is protected during transmission. The file posts through HTTPS (Hypertext Transfer Protocol over SSL) to a web server and the data is protected with SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) 128-bit encryption. This encrypted protocol is the same standard used for Internet financial transactions.

Q: What if the Treasurer's Settlement Sheet and the Statement of Taxes (SOT) do not reconcile?

The Treasurer's Settlement Sheet and the SOT should reconcile. If they do not, you must:
- Notify the municipality
- Provide DOR with a detailed explanation why the Treasurer's Settlement Sheet does not reflect what is reported on the SOT
- If the discrepancy is due to incorrect information on the SOT, amend the SOT to correct any identified errors

Q: How often do Managed Forest (MFL) rates change and how are we notified?
A: Rates can change every five years. The last rate update occurred in 2023; prior rates change in 2018. The next rate update will be 2028. DOR updates the form and instructions, emails municipalities with the new rates, and discusses the changes in training opportunities.

Q: Can I amend the Treasurer's Settlement Sheet?

Yes. You may amend the Treasurer's Settlement by using either the file transfer or e-file method. If a municipality has a duplicate file transfer, DOR recognizes it as amended.
Note: When using the e-file form, the report type will show "Amended," complete all required information and submit. Print and/or save the amended copy for your records.

A:

Q: What is the definition of a waste treatment facility?
A: All property purchased or constructed to be used exclusively and directly to remove, store or cause a physical or chemical change in industrial waste or air contaminants for the purpose of reducing or eliminating pollution of surface waters, air or waters of the state. (sec. 70.11(21)(am), Wis. Stats.)

Q: What does "used exclusively" mean?
A: "Used exclusively" means the property's sole purpose is to control or eliminate pollution. The property may have other uses if they do not exceed 5 percent of the total use.

Q: What is industrial waste?
A:
- Any gas, liquid or solid matter resulting from a process of industry, manufacture, trade, business or the development of any natural resource
- Industrial waste has no monetary value and would otherwise be considered superfluous or discarded material
- Industrial waste can be used to produce heat or steam for a manufacturing process if the fuel consists of one of the following: 95 percent or more industrial waste that would otherwise be superfluous or discarded material 50 percent or more of wood chips, sawdust, or other wood residue from the paper and wood products manufacturing process, if the wood chips, sawdust, or other wood residue would otherwise be superfluous or discarded
- 95 percent or more industrial waste that would otherwise be superfluous or discarded material
- 50 percent or more of wood chips, sawdust, or other wood residue from the paper and wood products manufacturing process, if the wood chips, sawdust, or other wood residue would otherwise be superfluous or discarded
Any gas, liquid or solid matter resulting from a process of industry, manufacture, trade, business or the development of any natural resource
Industrial waste has no monetary value and would otherwise be considered superfluous or discarded material
Industrial waste can be used to produce heat or steam for a manufacturing process if the fuel consists of one of the following:

50 percent or more of wood chips, sawdust, or other wood residue from the paper and wood products manufacturing process, if the wood chips, sawdust, or other wood residue would otherwise be superfluous or discarded

Q: What are air contaminants?
A:
- Air contaminants include : dust, fumes, mist, liquid, smoke, other particulate matter, vapor, gas, odorous substances or a combination of  the above
- Air contaminants do not include : uncombined water vapor (sec. 285.01(1), Wis. Stats.)
Air contaminants include
: dust, fumes, mist, liquid, smoke, other particulate matter, vapor, gas, odorous substances or a combination of  the above

(sec. 285.01(1), Wis. Stats.)

Q: What property qualifies for this exemption?
A:
- Dust collection systems
- Air cleaners
- Electrostatic precipitators
- Equipment used to remove smoke or fumes from welders
- Scrubbers used to remove air pollutants
- Wastewater pretreatment systems
- Waste holding tanks
- Wood waste burning process boilers
- Aerators
- Ridge and furrow systems and industrial wastewater holding ponds
- Thermal incinerators
- Gas vapor recovery equipment at gas stations
- Paint booths
- Makeup air units replacing air removed from the interior of a building by other equipment or processes with air from outside of the building
- Equipment used to compact or bale waste to reduce volume
- Storage tanks used outside of production process
- Equipment used for sewage treatment or garbage handling
- Conversion of a furnace from one type of fuel to another type of fuel
- Equipment treating uncombined water vapor (ex: steam)
- Unnecessary siltation resulting from operations, including ​washing of vegetables or raw food products, gravel washing, stripping of lands for development of subdivisions, highways, quarries and gravel pits, mine drainage, cleaning of vehicles or barges, or gross neglect of land erosion
- Smokestacks with increased height to diffuse emissions over a wider area
- Monitoring equipment that is not a component or integral part of a waste treatment facility
- Equipment used to remove trimmings or scraps from the production process when those items have monetary value
- Land used to dispose industrial waste and also used to grow agricultural products that are sold

Q: Is bio-gas equipment eligible for a waste treatment exemption?
A: No. As of January 1, 2014, bio-gas energy systems are exempt under state law (sec. 70.111(18), Wis. Stats.).

Q: If I sell the crop grown on my agricultural land where a food processor or manufacturer spreads wastewater, does the land qualify for the waste treatment exemption?
A:
- Cuts the cover crop and lets it lie in the field
- Leases property to a farmer; the farmer plants, harvests and feeds the crop to his own cattle
- Grows the crop and allows an area farmer to harvest and feed the crop to the farmer's cattle
- Allows an area farmer, at no charge, to grow, harvest and feed the crop to the farmer's cattle
- Leases property to a farmer; the farmer plants, harvests and sells the cover crop
- Grows, harvests and uses the crop in his/her own manufacturing process (ex: canning company)
- Harvests the crop and sells it
- Sells the crop instead of feeding it to his cattle
No. Whenever a crop is sold, the land no longer qualifies for the exemption. Below are examples of what qualifies and what is taxable.

Q: How do I claim and maintain this exemption and what type of records do I need to keep?
A:
Each year, manufacturers must report waste treatment property on the manufacturing self-reporting forms due annually on March 1. Owners must retain a list of assets classified as exempt waste treatment at their place of business. The Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) will inspect this asset list.
​Real Estate

M-R Form: Wisconsin Manufacturing Real Estate Return, Schedule R-6.

Q: What if DOR determines that property recorded on my M-Form does not qualify for exemption? Can I appeal the decision?
A: Yes. If DOR determines your property is taxable, you may appeal. If you are a manufacturer, the value of the property denied for the waste treatment exemption is added to your manufacturing real estate​ assessment. You may appeal your full value manufacturing assessment to the Board of Assessors.

Q: How do I know if a Tax Incremental District (TID) is affected by 2023 Act 12 ?
A: Review the TID's creation and territory amendment documents to identify whether the TID's base value includes personal property accounts. If the base value includes personal property, review with the assessor to determine whether the personal property is exempted by 2023 Act 12.

Q: How should a municipality submit an adjustment request?
A:
Complete the Personal Property Removal Workbook and email it to tif@wisconsin.gov.
- List all personal property included in the TID's base value that is tax exempt as of January 1, 2024
- Do not include personal property assessed as real estate (ex: buildings on leased land)
- If you are unsure whether personal property in the TID's base value is tax exempt in 2024, review with your municipal assessor

and email it to tif@wisconsin.gov.

If you are unsure whether personal property in the TID's base value is tax exempt in 2024, review with your municipal assessor

Q: Why should a municipality submit an adjustment request?
A:
Personal property exempted under 2023 Act 12 will be removed from the TID's current year value beginning in 2024. Adjusting the TID's base value by removing the exempt personal property allows for the correct increment calculation. Starting in 2024, the TID's assessed value does not include personal property.

will be removed from the TID's current year value beginning in 2024. Adjusting the TID's base value by removing the exempt personal property allows for the correct increment calculation. Starting in 2024, the TID's assessed value does not include personal property.

Q: What is the deadline to submit an adjustment request?
A:
October 31 each year is the deadline to submit a request for the following tax year.
DOR will review requests received:
- By October 31, 2024 for adjustment in the 2025 tax year
- Between November 1, 2024 and October 31, 2025 for adjustment in the 2026 tax year

Between November 1, 2024 and October 31, 2025 for adjustment in the 2026 tax year

Q: There was no personal property assessed in the TID for 2023. Does this mean there was no personal property included in the base value? Does the municipality still need to submit an adjustment request?
A: Personal property included in the TID's base value may be different than the personal property currently assessed in the TID. Review the TID's creation and territory amendment documents to identify if the TID's base value includes personal property. You only need to submit an adjustment request if personal property was included in the TID's base value and it is exempt starting in 2024.

Q: How does a TID personal property base value adjustment affect the TID's increment?
A:
- A TID's current value minus the base value equals the value increment
- Before January 1, 2024, taxable personal property assessed in the TID was included in the TID's current value and contributed to a TID's tax increment
- Removing exempt personal property from the base value ensures both the TID's base value and current value exclude exempt personal property value

Removing exempt personal property from the base value ensures both the TID's base value and current value exclude exempt personal property value

Q: Does the municipality have to submit a Personal Property Removal Workbook every year?
A:
No, submit one Personal Property Removal Workbook for each TID that includes personal property in the base. If your municipality already submitted a request, you do not need to resubmit.

Personal Property Removal Workbook
for each TID that includes personal property in the base. If your municipality already submitted a request, you do not need to resubmit.

Q: How do we complete the Personal Property Removal Workbook if the base value documents do not include all the information requested on the workbook, such as account numbers or addresses?
A:
When completing the "PP – Base Values" worksheet in the Personal Property Removal Workbook , provide the available information from the TID's creation and territory amendment documents. If specific information is not available on creation or territory amendment documents, leave those columns blank. DOR must be able to match the accounts on the "PP – Base Values" worksheet to the TID's creation and territory amendment documents.
When completing the "PP – Base Values" worksheet in the
Personal Property Removal Workbook
, provide the available information from the TID's creation and territory amendment documents. If specific information is not available on creation or territory amendment documents, leave those columns blank. DOR must be able to match the accounts on the "PP – Base Values" worksheet to the TID's creation and territory amendment documents.

Q: A municipality created a TID in 2023. The 2023 values include personal property that will be exempt due to 2023 Act 12. Do we still need to submit an adjustment request or will DOR adjust these TIDs automatically?
A: Since 2023 Act 12 is effective on January 1, 2024, DOR must include personal property values when establishing the base value for TIDs created in 2023. A municipality must complete and submit the Personal Property Adjustment Request for 2023 TID creations that include personal property exempt under 2023 Act 12.

Q: Does completing the adjustment request affect the amount of personal property aid the TID receives?
A: No, a TID's personal property aid is determined by its 2023 personal property value. The TID personal property adjustment request only affects the TID's base value.

Q: Is a TID created in 2023 eligible for personal property aid?
A:
No, the aid applies to TIDs on the 2023 tax/assessment roll. A TID created in 2023 will be added to the tax/assessment roll in 2024. See TID Creation Timeframes .
No, the aid applies to TIDs on the 2023 tax/assessment roll. A TID created in 2023 will be added to the tax/assessment roll in 2024.
See TID Creation Timeframes
.

Q: What is an allocation amendment?
A: An allocation amendment allows a TID with excess funds (the donor) to transfer funds to another TID (the recipient).

Q: Which TID type can allocate to another?
A:
See the TID Allocation Amendment Types .
See the
TID Allocation Amendment Types
.

Q: Can a  municipality allocate increment between its Tax Incremental Districts (TIDs) with different overlying  taxing jurisdictions?
A:
No. State law (sec. 66.1105(6)(f)1.a , Wis. Stats.) requires that both Donor and Recipient TIDs have the same overlying taxing jurisdictions.
No. State law (sec.
66.1105(6)(f)1.a
, Wis. Stats.) requires that both Donor and Recipient TIDs have the same overlying taxing jurisdictions.

Q: Which TID project plan should a municipality amend to allocate increment from one TID to another, the Donor TID or Recipient TID?
A:
A municipality must amend the Donor TID's project plan. For details on how to complete an allocation amendment, see Municipal TIF Project Plan and/or Allocation Amendments .
A municipality must amend the Donor TID's project plan. For details on how to complete an allocation amendment, see
Municipal TIF Project Plan and/or Allocation Amendments
.

Q: If a municipality amends both TID 1 and TID 2 to share increment with TID 3, how many updated project plans are needed?
A: If the municipality is amending TID 1 and TID 2 to become Donor TIDs, it must update the project plan for each TID. The economic feasibility section of each project plan must show that the Donor TID has extra increment to share.

Q: Does the public hearing notice for an allocation amendment need to include the amount of the donation?
A:
Yes, the public hearing notice must include the estimated donation amount. The notice for any TID amendment must include the purpose and cost of the amendment. For assistance, see the sample notices on the TIF Public Notices web page.
Yes, the public hearing notice must include the estimated donation amount. The notice for any TID amendment must include the purpose and cost of the amendment. For assistance, see the sample notices on the TIF
Public Notices
web page.

Q: After a municipality completes an allocation amendment, can the municipality decide not to allocate the funds?
A: Yes. The municipality can (for whatever reason) choose not to allocate after completing the allocation amendment. There is no additional action required if this occurs.

Q: If a Donor TID paid all its project costs, can it stay open solely to allocate to another TID?
A: Yes. If the Donor TID has not reached its maximum life, after the Donor TID's allocation amendment resolution is approved, it can stay open to allocate funds to another TID.

Q: After a TID becomes a donor, can the municipality amend the donor TID's project plan to add new project costs?
A:
Yes. The municipality can amend its project plan to add new project costs if the donor TID has not reached the end of its expenditure period.
After the donor TID's expenditure period ends, the municipality can continue to donate funds but cannot amend the plan to add new project costs.
Yes. The municipality can amend its project plan to add new project costs
if
the donor TID has not reached the end of its expenditure period.
After the donor TID's expenditure period ends, the municipality can continue to donate funds but cannot amend the plan to add new project costs.

Q: When can an allocation transfer take place?
A:
If funds are available from the Donor TID, the allocation transfer can occur after the municipal resolution is adopted and the JRB approves the allocation amendment.
After the JRB approves the amendment, the municipality can transfer funds according to the project plan without requesting JRB approval for each transfer.

Q: Can allocations be made after the expenditure period?
A: Yes. After the Donor TID's expenditure period ends, the municipality can allocate funds until the Donor TID reaches its maximum life.

Q: Can a municipality amend a TID to be a donor after the end of the TID's expenditure period?
A: Yes. The municipality can adopt an allocation amendment resolution after the donor TID's expenditure period ends. The municipality must adopt the amendment resolution before the donor or recipient TIDs reach their maximum life.

Q: What does project costs for "low-cost housing" mean for a mixed-use or industrial type recipient?
A:
Project plans for a mixed-use or industrial type TID must include costs to create, provide, or rehabilitate low-cost housing to become a recipient of increment funds from a donor TID.
State law does not define the term "low-​cost housing." The municipality should consult its attorney to determine if the recipient TID's costs meet the requirement.
The municipality is responsible for providing an explanation of how the recipient TID's project plan meets the requirement in sec. 66.1105(6)(f)2.a. , Wis. Stats. The Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) does not review or approve project costs. However, DOR confirms the recipient TID meets the requirements to receive allocated funds.
Project plans for a mixed-use or industrial type TID must include costs to create, provide, or rehabilitate low-cost housing to become a recipient of increment funds from a donor TID.
State law does not define the term "low-​cost housing." The municipality should consult its attorney to determine if the recipient TID's costs meet the requirement.
The municipality is responsible for providing an explanation of how the recipient TID's project plan meets the requirement in sec.
66.1105(6)(f)2.a.
, Wis. Stats. The Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) does not review or approve project costs. However, DOR confirms the recipient TID meets the requirements to receive allocated funds.

Q: Can the municipality create a Tax Incremental District (TID) that includes annexed parcels before approving the annexation?
A:
No. The municipality annexing the property must approve the annexation ordinance before the municipality can adopt the TID creation resolution.
No. The municipality annexing the property must approve the annexation ordinance
before
the municipality can adopt the TID creation resolution.

Q: What additional documents does a municipality have to provide to the Wisconsin Department of Revenue if a TID creation or territory amendment includes annexed parcels?
A:
When parcels annexed after January 1 of the TID creation or amendment year are included in the TID, the municipality must provide:
- Separate set of base value forms for the annexed parcels
- Town clerk and assessor must provide the necessary information
- List the town parcel numbers – include the new (city or village) parcel numbers, if available
- Copies of the annexation documents including the municipal ordinance approving the annexation
When parcels annexed after January 1 of the TID creation or amendment year are included in the TID, the municipality must provide:
Separate set of
base value forms
for the annexed parcels
Town clerk and assessor must provide the necessary information
List the town parcel numbers – include the new (city or village) parcel numbers, if available
Copies of the annexation documents including the municipal ordinance approving the annexation

Q: Which parcel numbers should be shown (town or city/village) on the TID map? The town parcel numbers or the city/village parcel numbers?
A: When a TID includes parcels annexed after January 1 of the creation or amendment year, show the town parcel numbers. The parcel numbers on the map must match the value forms and the assessment roll.

Q: If annexed property is included in a TID and a court later reverses the annexation, how is the TID affected?
A: If a court order reverses the annexation, the municipality must complete a territory amendment to remove the affected property from the TID. A TID can only include property in the municipality that created the TID.

Q: If a town is annexed by a city before a TID created by the town under a cooperative agreement reaches its maximum life, can the city continue to collect the increments to pay for the town projects?
A:
Yes. Under state law (sec. 66.1105(16)(c) , Wis. Stats.), when a town TID created under a cooperative agreement with a city (or village) is annexed by that city (or village), the city (or village) administers the TID as if it were created by that city (or village).
Yes. Under state law (sec.
66.1105(16)(c)
, Wis. Stats.), when a town TID created under a cooperative agreement with a city (or village) is annexed by that city (or village), the city (or village) administers the TID as if it were created by that city (or village).

Q: Where can I find annexation ordinances for a specific municipality?
A:
The Wisconsin Department of Administration (DOA) approves and publishes annexation ordinances statewide. To view the list, visit the DOA Municipal Data System-Ordinances .
The Wisconsin Department of Administration (DOA) approves and publishes annexation ordinances statewide. To view the list, visit the DOA
Municipal Data System-Ordinances
.

A:
Under state law, a municipality must complete the following audits and reports:
Municipality must complete three Certified Public Accountant (CPA) audits during the TID's life.
Municipalities with an active TID must e-file a TID Annual Report ( Form PE-300 ) with DOR for each TID.

Q: Can the municipal audit take the place of the TID Annual Report?
A:
No. A municipality must e-file a TID Annual Report ( Form PE-300 ) by July 1 with DOR.
No. A municipality must e-file a TID Annual Report (
Form PE-300
) by July 1 with DOR.

Q: Does the first audit occur when the municipality reaches 30% of the capital expenditures or 30% of the total expenditures?
A: The first audit should be completed after the municipality paid 30% of the expected total TID costs, based on the current project plan. The total costs include any eligible TID costs (ex: fees, financing or professional services).

Q: If the municipality amends the project plan to add costs after reaching 30% of project expenditures and completed a first audit, does the municipality need to complete another first audit?
A: Yes. If the municipality approved an amendment to increase the project costs and has not paid 30% of the amended project costs, the municipality must repeat the audit when reaching 30% of the amended project costs.

Q: If the municipality finished a TID's final audit, but continued to incur additional project costs, is the municipality required to complete another final audit?
A: Yes. The final audit must cover all TID costs. A municipality must complete another final audit after all project costs are paid or it must arrange to cover future expenditures (ex: bond payments) from a source other than the TID fund.

Q: If a municipality terminates a TID before the end of the expenditure period when the second audit is required, can the municipality skip the second audit?
A: Yes. However, the final audit is required and needs to explain the timing and why there is no  second audit. As an example, the second audit was not required because the TID terminated early and never reached 12 months after the end of the expenditure period.

Q: What determines the last reporting year for the TID Annual Report ( Form PE-300 )?
A:
The municipal termination resolution adoption date determines the last year a municipality must file the TID Annual Report. See the TID Termination Timeframes table for details.
The municipal termination resolution adoption date determines the last year a municipality must file the TID Annual Report. See the
TID Termination Timeframes
table for details.

Q: Our municipality terminated a TID before April 15 this year. Why is the Annual Report still required?
A: Each year, the municipality must file the TID Annual Report with the prior year's revenues and expenditures. When the municipality terminates the TID by April 15 of the current year, it was still active in the prior tax year, so the municipality must file the Annual Report.

Q: What determines the first reporting year for the TID Annual Report?
A:
The municipal creation resolution adoption date determines the first year a municipality must file the TID Annual Report. See the TID Creation Timeframes table for details.
The municipal creation resolution adoption date determines the first year a municipality must file the TID Annual Report. See the
TID Creation Timeframes
table for details.

Q: When completing the TID Annual Report for the first time, how should a municipality account for expenses in the prior year when the Annual Report was not required?
A: The municipality should work with an accountant or auditor to determine whether to include the expenses on the first Annual Report or keep them separate. The municipality must document these expenses and include them in the TID Final Accounting Report at the end of the TID's life.

Q: How does the municipality determine the amount of "future costs" and "future revenue" on the TID Annual Report?
A:
The municipality can use a recent cash flow statement and/or the most recent approved project plan to estimate these amounts.
- Future costs – expected amount of TID eligible costs during the remaining life of the TID
- Future revenue – expected amount of revenue during the remaining life of the TID
The municipality can use a recent cash flow statement and/or the most recent approved project plan to estimate these amounts.
Future costs – expected amount of TID eligible costs during the remaining life of the TID
Future revenue – expected amount of revenue during the remaining life of the TID

Q: How does the municipality determine the "Levy Increase Attributable to TID Net New Construction" on the TID Annual Report?
A:
Section 6 of the TID Annual R​eport shows the TID new construction values (as reported by the assessor) and calculates the maximum possible levy increase specific to TID net new construction.
The municipality must enter the amount it actually levied that was due to TID new construction. This amount can be zero. It cannot be greater than the amount in the "Allowable Levy Increase Attributable to TID Net New Construction" column.
The municipality should review the Statement of Taxes for the TIDAR reporting year to determine how much the municipality levied. Then review the Levy Limit Worksheet for the same year to determine the allowable levy.
The TID Annual Report is informational only. It does not affect the Levy Limit Worksheet.
- If the municipality levied the full amount allowed, then the "Levy Increase Attributable to TID Net New Construction" is likely the same as the "Allowable Levy Increase Attributable to TID Net New Construction"
- If the municipality levied less than the full amount allowed, it must determine how much of the levied amount  was due to TID net new construction. The reason the municipality levied less than the allowable amount may affect how a municipality determines the "Levy Increase Attributable to TID Net New Construction" amount.
- When the "Allowable Levy Increase Attributable to TID Net New Construction" is zero or negative, the form auto-fills "0" in "Levy Increase Attributable to TID Net New Construction"
- If there are multiple TIDs, the number entered on the first report filed will auto-fill on each future Annual Report

Q: Can a municipality use TIF funds to pay a Certified Public Accountant (CPA) to complete the required audits and Annual Reports?
A: Yes. Under state law, professional services are an allowable TID expenditure.

Q: Can a municipality use TIF funds to pay for Annual Report penalties?
A: No. Under state law, penalty payments are not an allowable TID expenditure.

Q: Does the Joint Review Board (JRB) need to meet before the municipality e-files the TID Annual Report(s)?
A: No. Under state law, the JRB must meet on July 1 or when the report becomes available. The law does not state whether the meeting must occur before or after e-filing the report with DOR.

Q: When a municipality schedules the JRB meeting, can the municipality email the TID Annual Report(s) to the JRB before the meeting?
A:
Yes. State law requires the municipality to provide the JRB copies of the report. However, state law does not require a municipality to provide the report before the meeting and does not require a specific distribution method.
State law requires the JRB meet to review the report and the TID's status/performance. For each JRB meeting, the municipality must publish a notice at least five days before it holds the meeting. At the meeting, it may be helpful to provide paper copies of the report.

Q: Does the JRB need to vote to approve or reject the annual reports, or does it just need to review the Annual Reports?
A: State law only requires the JRB meet to review the reports. The JRB does not need to adopt a resolution approving or rejecting the reports.

Q: Does a municipality need to provide DOR with documentation stating the JRB met to review the TID Annual Report?
A: No. The municipality should keep a record of the JRB meeting notice and minutes in its TID files.

Q: Can a municipality update its TID Annual Report after the report is submitted?
A:
Yes. After filing an original TID Annual R​eport, a municipality may amend the report in My DOR Government Account through November 1.
Yes. After filing an original TID Annual R​eport, a municipality may amend the report in
My DOR Government Account
through November 1.

Q: When an error is found in a TID Annual Report after the amendment deadline of November 1, how should a municipality correct the report?
A: After discovering an error in the TID Annual Report, a municipality should present the corrected report at the next JRB meeting and have revised numbers available for the public upon request. The original published report remains on DOR's website for seven years.

Q: If a municipality settles a claim on a property within a TID and issues a tax refund, how should the tax refund be reported on Form PE-300?
A:
Property tax refunds are not an eligible TID project cost. Do not include a property tax refund on the TID Annual Report (Form PE-300). Eligible TID project costs are defined in sec. 66.1105(2)(f) , Wis. Stats.
Property tax refunds are not an eligible TID project cost. Do not include a property tax refund on the TID Annual Report (Form PE-300). Eligible TID project costs are defined in sec.
66.1105(2)(f)
, Wis. Stats.

Q: Are TID statistical reports available?
A:
Yes. Review the DOR reports web page and select the category "Tax Incremental Financing" for information, including yearly data, active TIDs, value limit, and changes in TID values.
Yes. Review the
DOR reports
web page and select the category "Tax Incremental Financing" for information, including yearly data, active TIDs, value limit, and changes in TID values.

Q: What is a base value redetermination?
A: A base value redetermination is a type of amendment. A municipality may amend a Tax Incremental District (TID) to request that DOR reduce the TID's base value to its current value. To qualify, the TID's current year value must be at least 10% below the TID's base value for two consecutive years.

Q: When redetermining a base value, does the Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) use the Tax Incremental District's (TID's) current equalized value or the TID's lowest historic value to set the new base value?
A: DOR sets the new base value to the TID's equalized value as of the date of the municipality's redetermination resolution.

Q: What years should the municipality use to determine the equalized values two-year, 10% decline?
A:
Use the two most current years available based on when the municipality adopts the redetermination resolution.
If the municipality adopts the resolution:
- Between January 1 and August 14 — use the prior two years' values
- On or after August 15 through December 31 — use the current year value and prior year value
Use the two most current years available based on when the municipality adopts the redetermination resolution.
If the municipality adopts the resolution:
Between January 1 and August 14 —
use the prior two years' values
On or after August 15 through December 31 —
use the current year value and prior year value

Q: What steps must a municipality complete for a base value redetermination amendment?
A:
The municipality must:
See the TIF Base Value Redetermination web page for the required steps. See the TID Checklist for more information.
- Revise the project plan
- Hold the required meetings and a public hearing
- Adopt the necessary resolutions
The municipality must:
Revise the project plan
Hold the required meetings and a public hearing
Adopt the necessary resolutions

TIF Base Value Redetermination
web page for the required steps. See the
TID Checklist
for more information.

Q: The amended project plan requires selecting Option (3), (4) or (5) from sec. 66.1105(5)(i) , Wis. Stats. What impact do these three options have on the project plan?
A:
Option 3 - (sec. 66.1105(5)(i)3. )
Option 4 - (sec. 66.1105(5)(i)4. )
Option 5 - (sec. 66.1105(5)(i)5. )
- At least 51% of the public  infrastructure improvement's value must be financed by a private developer or entity
- Development agreement is required to receive cash grants which will solely repay the developer or entity for public infrastructure costs
- Municipality expects to pay all project costs within 90% of the TID's remaining life
- Expenditures may be made only within the first half of the TID's maximum life
- Joint Review Board can unanimously approve additional expenditures but not beyond the original expenditure period

Q: In Option (4), do the project costs which must be paid within 90% of the TID's remaining life, include debt service?
A:
Yes. The amended project plan must demonstrate the TID will have sufficient revenue to pay off debt and all project costs within 90% of the TID's remaining life. After all project costs are paid, the municipality must terminate the TID.
Yes. The amended project plan must demonstrate the TID will have sufficient revenue to pay off debt and
all
project costs within 90% of the TID's remaining life. After all project costs are paid, the municipality must terminate the TID.

Q: In Option (4), how is the TID's remaining life calculated?
A:
Example:
- Determine the TID's maximum life (review the Active TIDs report)
- Determine the TID's redetermination year: Municipal resolution adopted January 1 to September 30 — redetermination year is the year the resolution is adopted Municipal resolution adopted October 1 to December 31 — redetermination year is the year after the year the resolution is adopted
- Municipal resolution adopted January 1 to September 30 — redetermination year is the year the resolution is adopted
- Municipal resolution adopted October 1 to December 31 — redetermination year is the year after the year the resolution is adopted
- Subtract the redetermination year from the maximum life year
- Multiply the difference by (0.9)
- Add the result to the TID's redetermination year
- Municipality adopted a resolution to create a mixed-use on TID April 1, 2017; the maximum life is April 1, 2037
- Municipal redetermination resolution is adopted April 1, 2019; this is a 2019 redetermination
- 2037 (maximum life) – 2019 (redetermination year) = 18 years of life remaining
- 18 X (0.9) = 16 years is 90% of the remaining life
- 2019 (redetermination year) + 16 years = 2035; the municipality must pay all costs and adopt a termination resolution by April 1, 2035
Determine the TID's maximum life (review the
Active TIDs
report)
Determine the TID's redetermination year:
Municipal resolution adopted January 1 to September 30 — redetermination year is the year the resolution is adopted
Municipal resolution adopted October 1 to December 31 — redetermination year is the year after the year the resolution is adopted
Subtract the redetermination year from the maximum life year
Multiply the difference by (0.9)
Add the result to the TID's redetermination year
Example:
Municipality adopted a resolution to create a mixed-use on TID April 1, 2017; the maximum life is April 1, 2037
Municipal redetermination resolution is adopted April 1, 2019; this is a 2019 redetermination
2037 (maximum life) – 2019 (redetermination year) = 18 years of life remaining
18 X (0.9) = 16 years is 90% of the remaining life
2019 (redetermination year) + 16 years = 2035; the municipality must pay all costs and adopt a termination resolution by April 1, 2035

Q: In Option (5), do "expenditures" include debt service?
A:
No. With this option, the municipality may only take on project costs within the first half of the TID's maximum life. Debt payments may continue through the TID's maximum life. Also, see Municipal Expenditures and Debt Common Question 1 .
No. With this option, the municipality may only take on project costs within the first half of the TID's maximum life. Debt payments may continue through the TID's maximum life. Also, see
Municipal Expenditures and Debt Common Question 1
.

Q: What is the difference between "all project costs" in Option (4) and "expenditures" in Option (5)?
A:
State law (sec. 66.1105 , Wis. Stats.), does not provide a specific definition of expenditures; however, DOR considers an expenditure to include any eligible project cost at the point it is incurred. It does not include repayment of debt for an eligible project cost.
State law (sec.
66.1105
, Wis. Stats.), does not provide a specific definition of expenditures; however, DOR considers an expenditure to include any eligible project cost at the point it is incurred. It does not include repayment of debt for an eligible project cost.

Q: If a municipality completes a base value redetermination amendment, how would the change affect the equalized value used for the apportionment of taxes?
A: The municipality's equalized value, minus the TID increment value, is used for the apportionment of taxes. When the TID's base value is reduced through a redetermination amendment, it may increase the TID's increment value. An increased TID increment value could reduce the municipality's equalized value used for the apportionment of taxes.

Q: Can a municipality with an Environmental Remediation (ER) TID request a base value redetermination?
A:
Only an ER TID created after November 29, 2017, under sec. 66.1105 , Wis. Stats., is eligible for a redetermination if it meets the decrement criteria (TID's current year value is at least 10% below the base value for two consecutive years). An ER TID created under sec. 66.1106 , Wis. Stats., is not eligible.
Only an ER TID created after November 29, 2017, under sec.
66.1105
, Wis. Stats., is eligible for a redetermination if it meets the decrement criteria (TID's current year value is at least 10% below the base value for two consecutive years). An ER TID created under sec.
66.1106
, Wis. Stats., is not eligible.

Q: Can a municipality with a distressed (or severely distressed) TID request a base value redetermination?
A: Yes. A distressed (or severely distressed) TID is eligible for a redetermination if it meets the decrement criteria (the TID's current year value is at least 10% below the base value for two consecutive years).

Q: Can a municipality include new project costs with the base value redetermination amendment?
A: Yes. The municipality must adopt a revised project plan as part of the base value redetermination amendment. The revised project plan may include new projects, but the plan must show the TID meets the decrement criteria and select Option (3), (4) or (5). The new costs must meet the requirements of the Option (3), (4) or (5) selected in the revised plan.

Q: When is the deadline to request a TID base value redetermination with DOR?
A:
The municipality must adopt a municipal resolution on or before September 30 of the amendment year and email the redetermination documents to DOR by October 31. DOR will provide the municipality the redetermined base value in the following year.
Example: The municipality adopts the redetermination resolution by September 30, 2026, and submits the required redetermination documents to DOR by October 31, 2026. DOR notifies the municipality of the new base value by March 2027. The redetermined base value is in effect for tax year 2027.
Redetermination documents include:
See Base Value Redetermination for additional information.
- Decrement worksheet showing the 10% decline for the past two years
- Form PE-605B with required documents
- Updated project plan
The municipality must adopt a municipal resolution on or before September 30 of the amendment year and email the redetermination documents to DOR by October 31. DOR will provide the municipality the redetermined base value in the following year.
Example:
The municipality adopts the redetermination resolution by September 30, 2026, and submits the required redetermination documents to DOR by October 31, 2026. DOR notifies the municipality of the new base value by March 2027. The redetermined base value is in effect for tax year 2027.
Redetermination documents include:
Decrement worksheet
showing the 10% decline for the past two years
Form PE-605B
with required documents
Updated project plan
See
Base Value Redetermination
for additional information.

Q: Can a municipality request that the JRB adopt resolutions to extend a TID and complete a base value redetermination amendment for the same TID at the same time?
A:
Yes. If the TID meets the extension criteria (see TID Extension Types ) and the decrement criteria, the municipality may request the JRB approve both at the same time. An extension changes the amount of time allowed for options (4 or 5) from sec. 66.1105(5)(i), Wis. Stats., explained in question 4 .
Yes. If the TID meets the extension criteria (see
TID Extension Types
) and the decrement criteria, the municipality may request the JRB approve both at the same time. An extension changes the amount of time allowed for options (4 or 5) from sec. 66.1105(5)(i), Wis. Stats., explained in
question 4
.

Q: What entities can create a Tax Incremental District (TID)?
A:
Cities, villages and towns can create TIDs. For detailed information on creating a TID, review our publications and website:
- TID checklist
- TIF manual
- TIF Municipal Creation web page
- TIF Town Creation webpage
Cities, villages and towns can create TIDs. For detailed information on creating a TID, review our publications and website:
TID checklist
TIF manual
TIF Municipal Creation
web page
TIF Town Creation
webpage

Q: Can a municipality create one TID in more than one county, or are two separate TIDs required?
A:
One TID can exist in more than one county. When creating a TID in more than one county, complete a separate Base Value Workbook for each county. Email both workbooks, along with the other required documents, to  tif@wisconsin.gov. See the TIF Municipal Creation web page for more information.
One TID can exist in more than one county. When creating a TID in more than one county, complete a separate
Base Value Workbook
for each county. Email both workbooks, along with the other required documents, to  tif@wisconsin.gov. See the
TIF Municipal Creation
web page for more information.

Q: Can a TID be in more than one school district?
A: Yes. List each school district and identify the parcels for each district on all the required base value forms.

Q: Can a city, village, or town create a joint TID?
A:
Yes. Two or more municipalities may enter into an intergovernmental cooperative agreement to jointly create a multijurisdictional TID , under state law (sec. 66.1105(18) , Wis. Stats.).
Yes. Two or more municipalities may enter into an intergovernmental cooperative agreement to jointly create a
multijurisdictional TID
, under state law (sec.
66.1105(18)
, Wis. Stats.).

Q: How long does it take to create a new TID?
A: Generally, the process requires a minimum of two months at the local level. The time required depends on how often the municipality meets and how long it takes to develop the TID​'s project plan and boundaries.

Q: What documents are required to create a municipal TID?
A:
All required TID creation documents are listed in the Due date/process section of the TIF Municipal Creation web page and must be emailed to tif@wisconsin.gov by October 31 of the creation year.
All required TID creation documents are listed in the Due date/process section of the
TIF Municipal Creation
web page and must be emailed to tif@wisconsin.gov by October 31 of the creation year.

Q: When is the TID creation deadline?
A:
The local legislative body must adopt the creation resolution by September  30 and email the required documents to tif@wisconsin.gov by October 31 of the creation year. DOR emails a base value certification letter by March of the following year. The municipality receives its first tax increment dollars the year after the certification.
See TID Creation Timeframes .
The local legislative body must adopt the creation resolution by September  30 and email the required documents to tif@wisconsin.gov by October 31 of the creation year. DOR emails a base value certification letter by March of the following year. The municipality receives its first tax increment dollars the year after the certification.
See
TID Creation Timeframes
.

Q: Does the Planning Commission have to hold a public hearing?
A:
Yes. If the municipality does not have a Planning Commission, it must create one following sec. 62.23 , Wis. Stats., or designate another authority to act in that capacity (ex: Community Development Authority (CDA) or Redevelopment Authority).
Yes. If the municipality does not have a Planning Commission, it must create one following sec.
62.23
, Wis. Stats., or designate another authority to act in that capacity (ex: Community Development Authority (CDA) or Redevelopment Authority).

Q: If the Planning Commission is only an advisory board to the municipality and does not have authority to pass resolutions, what should the Planning Commission provide?
A:
Provide a copy of the Planning Commission meeting minutes, documenting approval to both:
- Local legislative body
- DOR (as part of the TID documents)
Provide a copy of the Planning Commission meeting minutes, documenting approval to both:
Local legislative body
DOR (as part of the TID documents)

Q: If the Planning Commission denies a municipality's proposal to create a new TID, can the local legislative body overrule the Planning Commission and approve the TID?
A: No. The Planning Commission must adopt a project plan for a proposed TID before the local legislative body can approve the TID.

Q: Do we need to adjust the maps in the project plan if the municipality approves different boundaries than those recommended by the Planning Commission?
A: Yes. The maps in the final project plan must reflect the boundaries approved by the municipality and the Joint Review Board.

Q: Are there requirements for resolution wording?
A:
Yes. See the Resolution Checklist for the requirements for each resolution (Planning Commission, local legislative body and Joint Review Board).
Yes. See the
Resolution Checklist
for the requirements for each resolution (Planning Commission, local legislative body and Joint Review Board).

Q: Is a two-thirds majority required to pass each of the resolutions to create a TID (Planning Commission, local legislative body and Joint Review Board)?
A: No, a two-thirds majority is not required. Each resolution must be passed by a simple majority of members.

Q: Can the municipality hold one public hearing when several TIDs are being created at the same time?
A: Yes. However, the public hearing notice must list each creation separately and the municipality must adopt a separate resolution for each TID.

Q: Can a property owner exclude their property from a TID?
A:
A property owner can request municipal officials exclude their property from a TID during the creation process. However, the municipality is not required to exclude that property.
If their property is already located within a TID, the property owner can request the municipality complete a territory subtraction amendment to have their property removed from the TID. However​ the municipality is not required to complete a subtraction to remove the property.
Note: The property in a TID is assessed the same way as property outside a TID. The municipal tax rate is the same whether the property is in or out of a TID.

Q: What year is used for the base value of parcels in a TID?
A:
For a creation resolution adopted between October 1, 2025, and September 30, 2026, use the assessment as of January 1, 2026. Use the assessed values as of the final adjournment by that year's Board of Review (BOR). Do not complete the Base Value Workbook until after the BOR.
For a creation resolution adopted between October 1, 2025, and September 30, 2026, use the assessment as of January 1, 2026. Use the assessed values as of the final adjournment by that year's Board of Review (BOR). Do not complete the
Base Value Workbook
until after the BOR.

Q: Is personal property included in a TID's base value?
A: No, effective January 1, 2024, personal property is tax exempt. TIDs created in 2024 or after do not include personal property in the TID’s base value.

Q: What are the TID types?
A:
The municipality creating the TID must declare a type in the resolution based on the type of property in the TID at the time of creation. See the Tax Incremental Finance (TIF) Manual , Section 1.5 Glossary, for definitions of each type.
Municipal TID types (created under sec. 66.1105 , Wis. Stats.):
Environmental Remediation TID type (created under sec. 66.1106 , Wis. Stats. — local legislative body resolution adopted before November 29, 2017).
Town TID  types (created under sec. 60.85 , Wis. Stats.):
- Blight
- Rehabilitation/conservation
- Industrial
- Mixed-use
- Environmental Remediation (local legislative body resolution adopted on or after November 29, 2017)
- Tourism
- Agriculture
- Forest
- Manufacturing

Q: How does a municipality calculate the percentage of property to determine the TID type?
A:
When creating a municipal TID (under sec. 66.1105 , Wis. Stats.), at least 50% of all TID property must be one of the following types:
To calculate the percentage, divide the acreage of all real property determined to be a specific type by the total acreage of the TID. The total TID acreage includes roads and exempt property.
When creating a town TID (under sec. 60.85 , Wis. Stats.), at least 75% of all TID property must be used for single project type: agriculture, forestry, manufacturing or tourism.

Q: Where do I find specific information on the different TID types?
A:
See the TID Criteria Matrix for TID life, standard extension, overlap option and expenditure period for each TID type.
See the
TID Criteria Matrix
for TID life, standard extension, overlap option and expenditure period for each TID type.

Q: What determines the TID's maximum life?
A:
The TID's maximum life is based on the creation date and the TID type. The creation date is the date the local legislative body adopted the creation resolution. The TID type is declared in the resolution. See the TID Criteria Matrix .
The TID's maximum life is based on the creation date and the TID type. The creation date is the date the local legislative body adopted the creation resolution. The TID type is declared in the resolution. See the
TID Criteria Matrix
.

Q: What is the  difference between a loan and a grant?
A:
Cash grant — when the municipality provides funds to an owner, developer, or lessee of land using Tax Incremental District (TID) increments and the funds are not paid back.
The project plan may also refer to a cash grant as a "developer incentive."
Loan versus a grant:
- Loan — must be paid back in full
- Grant — paid for by increments from property taxes; not required to be paid back
Cash grant — when the municipality provides funds to an owner, developer, or lessee of land using Tax Incremental District (TID) increments and the funds are not paid back.
The project plan may also refer to a cash grant as a "developer incentive."
Loan versus a grant:
Loan — must be paid back in full
Grant — paid for by increments from property taxes; not required to be paid back

Q: What are the requirements for a municipality to provide a cash grant using increment funds?
A:
Cash grants are not allowed for town TIDs created under sec. 60.85 , Wis. Stats.
- Municipality must have a signed development agreement to provide cash grants to property owners, lessees or developers
- Public hearing notice must indicate the TID costs include cash grants
Municipality must have a signed development agreement to provide cash grants to property owners, lessees or developers
Public hearing notice must indicate the TID costs include cash grants
Cash grants are not allowed for town TIDs created under sec.
60.85
, Wis. Stats.

Q: Is the municipality required to send a copy of the developer's agreement to the Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR)?
A: No. The municipality does not need to send the agreement to DOR. However, state law requires the municipality to send a copy of the developer's agreement to the Joint Review Board (JRB). After the TID is terminated, the municipality must save the agreement in the official TID records.

Q: When must the public hearing notice include the cash grant reference? Is an amount required?
A:
If the proposed project plan includes cash grants, the municipality must state this information in the published hearing notice under state law (sec. 66.1105(4)(e) , Wis. Stats.). The hearing notice does not need to include the purpose of the cash grant or list the exact amount.
If the proposed project plan includes cash grants, the municipality must state this information in the published hearing notice under state law (sec.
66.1105(4)(e)
, Wis. Stats.). The hearing notice does not need to include the purpose of the cash grant or list the exact amount.

Q: A municipality included cash grants in the original project plan. The municipality is now amending the plan. Does the municipality need to repeat the cash grant reference if no new cash grants are being added to the plan?
A: State law does not require the cash grant wording in this situation. However, continuing to include the cash grants information in public hearing notices provides consistent information to taxpayers.

Q: Who makes the decision on what to include in a developer's agreement?
A: The municipality and its attorney decide what information to include in the developer's agreement.

Q: Does the developer's agreement need to be finalized before the TID's creation resolution is adopted?
A:
No. The developer's agreement does not need to be finalized before the municipality adopts the creation resolution. However, the municipality must include:
- The developer incentive amount as a cost in the approved project plan
- A statement about the developer incentive in the public hearing notice
No. The developer's agreement does not need to be finalized before the municipality adopts the creation resolution. However, the municipality must include:
The developer incentive amount as a cost in the approved project plan
A statement about the developer incentive in the public hearing notice

Q: What extension types are available for Tax Incremental Districts (TIDs)?
A:
There are three types of extensions: Standard, Technical College, and Affordable Housing. Each extension has different requirements and exclusions.
- Standard – allows an extension (three or four years from the TID's maximum life, depending on TID type) if existing tax increments will not pay project costs within the TID maximum life
- Technical College – allows a three-year extension to the TID's maximum life if tax increments were negatively impacted by 2013 Act 145. The Act increased state aid to technical colleges and may have caused a decrease in tax increment revenue for some TIDs.
- Affordable Housing – allows an extension, up to one year from the resolution date, if the municipality uses the final year's increment to benefit affordable housing
There are three types of extensions: Standard, Technical College, and Affordable Housing. Each extension has different requirements and exclusions.
Standard – allows an extension (three or four years from the TID's maximum life, depending on TID type) if existing tax increments will not pay project costs within the TID maximum life
Technical College – allows a three-year extension to the TID's maximum life if tax increments were negatively impacted by 2013 Act 145. The Act increased state aid to technical colleges and may have caused a decrease in tax increment revenue for some TIDs.
Affordable Housing – allows an extension, up to one year from the resolution date, if the municipality uses the final year's increment to benefit affordable housing
For details on each extension type, review the
TID Extension Types
matrix.

Q: To extend the life of a TID, is the municipality required to complete the amendment process?
A: No. The municipality is not required to complete the Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) amendment forms or provide DOR an updated project plan. However, a municipality must document that the TID needs extra time to pay off existing debt or the TID has paid all its project costs and would like one additional year for affordable housing. The municipality must provide DOR an approved resolution for each extension type.

Q: When extending a TID's life, what documents must a municipality provide to the Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR)?
A: When the extension resolution is adopted, the municipality must email a scanned copy of the resolution to tif@wisconsin.gov. DOR then extends the TID life.

Q: When a municipality adopts an extension resolution to change the maximum life, does this change the expenditure period?
A:
No. An extension does not change the expenditure period. The expenditure period is five years shorter than the maximum life without the extension. For more information, see Municipal Expenditures and Debt Common Question 2 .
No. An extension does not change the expenditure period. The expenditure period is five years shorter than the maximum life without the extension. For more information, see
Municipal Expenditures and Debt Common Question 2
.

Q: For the Standard or Technical College extension, is the Joint Review Board (JRB) the only body that needs to approve the extension?
A: Yes. The municipality must either present the JRB with documents showing the TID cannot repay project costs within its maximum life or provide the JRB with an independent audit. The JRB must adopt a resolution approving the extension.

Q: Is a distressed TID eligible for the Standard or Technical College extension?
A:
Yes, a TID designated distressed may be extended using a Standard or Technical College extension, if the TID meets the requirements for these extensions. See TID Extension Types to determine if the TID is eligible.
Yes, a TID designated distressed may be extended using a Standard or Technical College extension, if the TID meets the requirements for these extensions. See
TID Extension Types
to determine if the TID is eligible.

Q: Is an industrial TID created between 1995 and 2004 eligible for the Standard extension?
A:
No. The law has no Standard extension for industrial TIDs created between 1995 and 2004. A municipality could consider requesting the Technical College extension if it needs more time to pay off a TID's existing debt. Other TID types not eligible for the Standard extension are listed in the TID Extension Types matrix.
No. The law has no Standard extension for industrial TIDs created between 1995 and 2004. A municipality could consider requesting the Technical College extension if it needs more time to pay off a TID's existing debt. Other TID types not eligible for the Standard extension are listed in the
TID Extension Types
matrix.

Q: Can a municipality request a Technical College extension for a TID created before 2014 if it added project costs after 2014?
A: Yes. If the TID was created before October​ 1, 2014, a municipality can request the three-year Technical College extension regardless of when the project costs were incurred or updated.

Q: Is the municipality required to inform the JRB when it adopts an Affordable Housing resolution to extend the TID an additional year?
A: No. The law does not require the municipality to notify the JRB; however, it would be beneficial for the municipality to inform the JRB of the Affordable Housing extension.

Q: When can a municipality request the Affordable Housing extension?
A:
A municipality can adopt an Affordable Housing extension resolution after it pays all the TID project costs. The Affordable Housing extension resolution must state the year the final tax increment was (or will be) received and describe how the funds will be used for affordable housing. The resolution can extend the TID's life for up to one year from the resolution date. The municipality must adopt a separate termination resolution before receiving an additional year's increment. April 15 is the deadline for a municipality to terminate a TID and have it removed from the same year's tax roll. Review the Termination Timeframes table for additional details.
A municipality can adopt an Affordable Housing extension resolution after it pays all the TID project costs. The Affordable Housing extension resolution must state the year the final tax increment was (or will be) received and describe how the funds will be used for affordable housing. The resolution can extend the TID's life for up to one year from the resolution date.
The municipality must adopt a separate termination resolution before receiving an additional year's increment. April 15 is the deadline for a municipality to terminate a TID and have it removed from the same year's tax roll. Review the
Termination Timeframes table
for additional details.

Q: Can a municipality adopt all three extension resolutions at the same time?
A:
No. The Standard and Technical College extensions are designed to allow more time to pay existing costs and debt. These extension resolutions can be adopted at the same time; however, a municipality cannot adopt an Affordable Housing extension resolution until all costs are paid. See TID Options Near Max Life document for more information.
No. The Standard and Technical College extensions are designed to allow more time to pay existing costs and debt. These extension resolutions can be adopted at the same time; however, a municipality cannot adopt an Affordable Housing extension resolution until all costs are paid. See
TID Options Near Max Life
document for more information.

Q: Does a municipality considering the Standard and Technical College extensions have to adopt both at the same time (before the maximum life)?
A: No. If the TID meets the criteria for both extension types, the municipality can adopt one of the extension resolutions and consider another before the end of the TID's extended life.

Q: Is the JRB required to approve a Technical College extension for three years or can it approve the extension for one or two years?
A:
If the municipality provides an independent audit demonstrating the need for the extension, the JRB must approve the extension for three years.
If the municipality does not provide an independent audit, the JRB can deny or approve the three-year extension. When the JRB approves an extension of less than three years or denies the extension entirely, the municipality may complete an independent audit to show the full three years are needed.
If the TID does not need the full three-year extension, the municipality can terminate the TID before the TID's extended life date.

Q: Is a municipality limited to using the affordable housing funds within the TID boundary?
A: No. The funds can be used anywhere in the municipality; however, at least 75% must be used for affordable housing and the remainder on housing in general.

Q: What is affordable housing?
A:
State law defines "affordable housing" as housing that costs a household no more than 30% of the household's gross monthly income.
State law defines "affordable housing" as housing that costs a household no more than 30% of the household's gross monthly income.
Example: for a household earning $3,000 per month, housing must cost $900 or less to be considered affordable.

Q: Can a municipality consider additional restrictions on the housing? For example, can a municipality require residents to make less than the average household income?
A: Yes, if the housing meets state law, the municipality can include additional requirements. A municipality should consult its attorney to confirm the proposed restrictions comply with state law.

Q: Does DOR have a list of eligible affordable housing costs?
A: No. Each municipality must identify its affordable housing needs and develop a plan for the funds. State law requires a municipality to use the funds for affordable housing and to describe how it will use the funds in its affordable housing extension resolution. The municipality should consult its attorney to determine whether the planned costs comply with state law.

Q: What are some examples of how municipalities use affordable housing funds?
A: Some municipalities set aside the affordable housing funds for large affordable housing developments. Others establish a revolving loan or grant program to increase home ownership or improve existing affordable housing. Each municipality should review its affordable housing needs and develop a plan for the funds before the TID reaches its maximum life.

Q: Is a municipality required to use the affordable housing funds within one year?
A: No. However, the municipality must remove the money from the TID fund to terminate the TID. The municipality should keep the funds for affordable housing use separate.

Q: Can a municipality extending a TID for affordable housing use the TID's final shared revenue payments (exempt computer or personal property aid) for affordable housing?
A: No. State law refers to using the final increment for affordable housing and does not mention using shared revenue payments for this purpose.

Q: Can a municipality extending a TID for affordable housing use more than one year of increment for affordable housing, or use the entire surplus in the TID fund for affordable housing?
A: No. The municipality may only use the amount of the final year's tax increment for affordable housing.

Q: Can a municipality extending a TID for affordable housing use a portion of the final increment to pay off costs and the remainder for affordable housing?
A:
Yes. The municipality must still follow all requirements for the affordable housing extension.
- Use at least 75% of the amount set aside for affordable housing and the remaining 25% on housing in general
- Adopt a resolution describing how it will use the funds and provide the resolution to DOR
- Uses $50,000 to pay remaining TID project costs (ex: final audit costs)
- Uses the remaining $200,000 for the affordable housing extension 75% (or $150,000) must be used on affordable housing 25% (or $50,000) may be used on housing in general
- 75% (or $150,000) must be used on affordable housing
- 25% (or $50,000) may be used on housing in general
Yes. The municipality must still follow all requirements for the affordable housing extension.
The municipality must:
Use at least 75% of the amount set aside for affordable housing and the remaining 25% on housing in general
Adopt a resolution describing how it will use the funds and provide the resolution to DOR
Example – TID's final tax increment is $250,000. The municipality:
Uses $50,000 to pay remaining TID project costs (ex: final audit costs)
Uses the remaining $200,000 for the affordable housing extension
75% (or $150,000) must be used on affordable housing
25% (or $50,000) may be used on housing in general

Q: Is a TID eligible for the Affordable Housing extension if its life was extended for other reasons (ex: declared distressed, donor to distressed, granted a Standard extension or Technical College extension)?
A: Yes. A TID that was extended for other reasons is eligible for the Affordable Housing extension; however, only TIDs created under sec. 66.1105, Wis. Stats. are eligible for the Affordable Housing extension. Town TIDs (created under sec. 60.85, Wis. Stats.) and ER TIDs (created under sec. 66.1106, Wis. Stats.) are not eligible.

Q: Can a municipality adopt one resolution that includes both an Affordable Housing extension and the TID termination?
A: No. A municipality must adopt separate resolutions. The Affordable Housing extension resolution must state the length of the extension, not to exceed 12 months from the date of the resolution. Before the Affordable Housing extension period ends, the municipality must adopt a separate termination resolution. The termination resolution formally ends the TID.

Q: How does the municipality identify the affordable housing funds on the TID Final Accounting Report (Form PE-110)?
A:
The municipality can do either of the following:
- Include the amounts in the appropriate category (ex: capital expenditures) if the municipality uses the funds before the TID terminates
- Use "Transfers to other funds" or "Other expenditures" category if the municipality moves the funds to a separate account, for later use, after the TID terminates

Q: Does DOR have a list of TIDs that were extended?
A:
The Active TIDs report includes a column for the Life Extended date. Any TID with an extension shows a date in this column, which is the end of the TID's extension period.

Q: What is the  difference between TIF and a Tax Incremental District (TID)?
A:
- TIF — an economic development technique to expand the property tax base. Property value increases fund site improvements that would not otherwise occur.
- TID — the actual physical area (whole parcels) designated for improvements using tax incremental financing
TIF —
an economic development technique to expand the property tax base. Property value increases fund site improvements that would not otherwise occur.
