the actual physical area (whole parcels) designated for improvements using tax incremental financing

Q: What is the Wisconsin  Department of Revenue's (DOR) role?
A:
- TIF is intended to be locally initiated and managed, with minimal State oversight. However, DOR cannot certify a tax incremental base until we determine procedures were followed, documents were completed correctly, and notices were provided timely.
- Facts supporting any document adopted or action taken by the local governing body are not subject to review by DOR. The municipality's documents and proposed project costs must comply with state law. A municipality is encouraged to consult an attorney and auditor with any questions.
- If you have questions about a specific project in a TID, contact the municipality or the members of the Joint Review Board (JRB) that approved the TID project plan and boundaries

Q: What statutes regulate TIF?

- Town — sec. 60.85 and sec. 60.23(32) , Wis. Stats.
- Environmental remediation (municipal resolution adopted before November 29, 2017) — sec. 66.1106 , Wis. Stats.

Q: How is TIF  funded?
A:
When a TID is created, the municipality and other taxing jurisdictions agree to support their normal operations from the existing tax base within the district. Property taxes for the school, county, technical college, and municipality are based on the taxable value of the TID at the time it is created.
The municipality funds development through the increases to the property values in the TID.  The taxes on the TID value increment (the difference between the TID's current value and the TID's base value), results in additional revenues collected for the district's fund. The municipality must use the funds to pay eligible TID costs. When costs are paid and the municipality closes the TID, the increased tax base is shared with all taxing jurisdictions.
The State of Wisconsin does not collect or pay tax increments to municipal governments.
When a TID is created, the municipality and other taxing jurisdictions agree to support their normal operations from the existing tax base within the district. Property taxes for the school, county, technical college, and municipality are based on the taxable value of the TID at the time it is created.
The municipality funds development through the increases to the property values in the TID.  The taxes on the TID value increment (the difference between the TID's current value and the TID's base value), results in additional revenues collected for the district's fund. The municipality must use the funds to pay eligible TID costs. When costs are paid and the municipality closes the TID, the increased tax base is shared with all taxing jurisdictions.
The State of Wisconsin does
not
collect or pay tax increments to municipal governments.

Q: Besides a municipality, what are the other taxing jurisdictions?
A: The other taxing jurisdictions are the school district, county, and technical college. A municipality may also have a lake district, sanitary district or metro sewer district.

Q: Are there limits on the use of TIF?
A:
Yes. State law limits a municipality's ability  to create new TIDs and add property to existing TIDs. The equalized value of property in the TID, plus the value increment of all existing TIDs cannot exceed 12% of the total municipal equalized value. This restriction does not apply to an Environmental Remediation TID created under sec. 66.1106 , Wis. Stats., or when subtracting territory from a TID. For more information, review the Value Limit Common Questions.

Q: What is the TID maximum life with or without extensions?
A:
The TID maximum life without an extension depends on the TID type declared in the creation resolution and the date the municipality adopted the resolution. For more information on the maximum life without an extension for each type, see the TID Criteria Matrix .
The municipality can approve an extension as a separate resolution later in a TID's life. The TID maximum life with an extension depends on the extension type. See TID Extension Types for extensions available including the length.

Q: What is the Joint Review Board?
A: The Joint Review Board (JRB) oversees a Tax Incremental District (TID). The JRB consists of one representative from each taxation jurisdiction within the specific TID (school district, technical college, county, municipality) and one public member.

Q: When does the initial JRB meeting for a creation or amendment have to be held?
A: The initial JRB meeting must be held within 14 days after the public hearing notice is published.

Q: Do the JRB meetings require a published notice?
A: Yes. For all JRB meetings, the municipality with the TID must publish a notice in a local newspaper, at least five days before the meeting.

Q: If a municipality creates a TID in two counties, which county has a representative on the JRB?
A: The county with the greatest value in the TID is represented on the JRB.

Q: If there are two lake districts in a TID, which one should have a representative on the JRB?
A: Neither. Only the school, county, technical college and municipality can appoint JRB representatives. However, the municipality must notify all affected taxing jurisdictions of the public hearing, including the lake districts.

Q: If there is an elementary and union high school district, which one has a representative on the JRB?
A: A representative from the elementary school and a representative from the union high school share one seat and each have one-half a vote.

Q: If a municipality amends a TID with additional territory that includes a new school district or county, should the new school district or county have a representative on the JRB?
A:
A territory amendment requires a new calculation to determine which of the school districts or counties in the TID has the majority of the land value. Whichever has the majority, has the voting representation on the JRB. The calculation to determine majority value is the existing base value plus the additional parcels' current value.
- If the amendment does not change the district with the majority value – the current standing JRB approves the amendment
- If the amendment changes the district with the majority value and the municipality does not have a standing JRB with that district in the majority – the municipality must form a new standing JRB. The new JRB, including the representative from the district with majority value, approves the amendment.
- If the amendment changes the district with the majority value and the municipality has a standing JRB with that district in the majority – the standing JRB, represented by the district with majority value, approves the amendment

Q: When a TID is created, how are the JRB's chairperson and public member determined?
A: The JRB members, by majority vote, choose the chairperson and public member. If the representative acting as chairperson resigns from the JRB, the members must elect a new chairperson by majority vote. If the public member resigns, the JRB must choose a new public member by majority vote.

Q: How soon can a JRB approve/deny a resolution after the local legislative body adopts the resolution?
A:
- For Municipal TIDs - the JRB must approve/deny a resolution anytime within 45 days after receiving the resolution from the local legislative body
- For Town TIDs created under sec 60.85, Wis. Stats., or Environmental Remediation TIDs created under sec. 66.1106, Wis. Stats. - the JRB must approve or deny a resolution within 10-45 days after receiving the resolution from the local legislative body
For Municipal TIDs -
the JRB must approve/deny a resolution anytime within 45 days after receiving the resolution from the local legislative body
For Town TIDs created under sec 60.85, Wis. Stats., or Environmental Remediation TIDs created under sec. 66.1106, Wis. Stats. -
the JRB must approve or deny a resolution within 10-45 days after receiving the resolution from the local legislative body

Q: Does a Tax Incremental District (TID) creation need unanimous JRB approval?
A: No. Only a majority approval vote is required.

Q: Is the majority vote based on all the JRB members or only the members who attend the meeting?
A: A majority of all JRB members must approve the TID. Therefore, except for a multijurisdictional TID, at least three "yes" votes are required. Any member who cannot attend a meeting should appoint a delegate to attend and vote on their behalf. Any member who does not attend or send a delegate is considered a "no" vote.

Q: After the JRB adopts the resolution, how soon does the Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) need to be notified?
A:
Under state law (sec. 66.1105(5)(cm) , Wis. Stats.), the municipal clerk must give DOR written notice within 60 days of adopting any amendment resolution. Although state law does not require this same notice for a creation resolution, municipalities should also notify DOR within 60 days.
Under state law (sec.
66.1105(5)(cm)
, Wis. Stats.), the municipal clerk must give DOR written notice within 60 days of adopting any amendment resolution. Although state law does not require this same notice for a creation resolution, municipalities should also notify DOR within 60 days.

Q: How often does the JRB need to meet after the TID is created?
A: At a minimum, the JRB must meet annually to review the TID's annual report, performance and status. The JRB must also meet to consider any amendments to the TID.

Q: Does the JRB need to vote to select a chairperson and public member at each year's meeting or when amending a TID?
A: No. Once the chairperson and public member are selected, no new vote is required. The chairperson and public member remain the same until they are no longer on the board.

Q: How many JRB members need to attend the meeting for it to take place?
A:
At least one-half of the members must attend a meeting. When one-half or more of the members of a governmental body attend, a meeting is assumed to be for official purposes (sec. 19.82(2) , Wis. Stats.).
At least one-half of the members must attend a meeting. When one-half or more of the members of a governmental body attend, a meeting is assumed to be for official purposes (sec.
19.82(2)
, Wis. Stats.).

Q: Are the JRB members required to attend meetings in person?
A:
Due to the complexity of TID project plans, meeting in person is considered best practice. However, JRB members may participate in meetings via telephone or video conference, if communication is two-way, so votes and comments can be heard by all attendees. JRB members may not vote by email. The municipality should consult its attorney to confirm JRB meetings and notices comply with open meetings law.
For more information, review the Joint Review Board section of the TIF Manual.

However, JRB members may participate in meetings via telephone or video conference, if communication is two-way, so votes and comments can be heard by all attendees. JRB members may not vote by email. The municipality should consult its attorney to confirm JRB meetings and notices comply with open meetings law.

Q: Where should the JRB meetings be held?
A:
When creating or amending a TID, the municipality should hold the JRB meeting locally so the affected members of the public can easily attend. The municipality should consider allowing both in-person and virtual options for the same meeting. This allows the public to attend using the method they prefer.
When reviewing the TID annual reports, the meeting may be held by one of the taxing jurisdictions (school, county, technical college) to review the reports from multiple municipalities.

Q: Can a municipality email correspondence to JRB members?
A: Yes, since state law does not define a distribution method for materials a municipality provides to JRB members.

Q: Since the JRB for any active TID is already established, does it still need to hold an organizational meeting when amending a TID?
A:
Yes. Under state law, (sec. 66.1105(4m)(a) , Wis. Stats.), the JRB must hold its first meeting to review the proposal within 14 days after the public hearing notice is published.  The organizational meeting provides the public an opportunity to learn about the amendment.
Yes. Under state law, (sec.
66.1105(4m)(a)
, Wis. Stats.), the JRB must hold its first meeting to review the proposal within 14 days after the public hearing notice is published.  The organizational meeting provides the public an opportunity to learn about the amendment.

Q: When a municipality has a standing JRB but is creating a new TID, should it reappoint a chairperson and public member for the new TID?
A:
The answer depends on whether the new TID includes the same overlying taxing jurisdictions (ex: school district, county and technical college) as the standing JRB. Each combination of taxing jurisdictions must have a separate JRB.
- Same overlying taxing jurisdictions as an existing TID – the existing (standing) JRB governs the new TID. The standing JRB does not appoint a new chairperson or public representative. Exception: The standing JRB must appoint a new chairperson or public representative when the position becomes vacant due to a resignation.
- Different overlying taxing jurisdictions than any existing TIDs – the JRB members for the new TID's taxing jurisdictions must elect the chairperson and public member, by majority vote, at the first meeting

Different overlying taxing jurisdictions than any existing TIDs –
the JRB members for the new TID's taxing jurisdictions must elect the chairperson and public member, by majority vote, at the first meeting

Q: When a taxing jurisdiction replaces their representative, do other members of the JRB have to approve the change?
A: No. Each taxing jurisdiction appoints a representative and can replace that representative when necessary without approval from the other JRB members.

Q: What are the criteria for selecting a public member?
A: State law does not define any requirements for the public member. The JRB members, by majority vote, choose the public member at the JRB's first meeting. A public member can be appointed as the JRB chairperson.

Q: Can the public member be employed by the municipality or county?
A: Yes. A public member may work for municipal, county, state or federal government.

Q: Does the public member need to live in the same municipality as the TID?
A: No. State law does not require the public member to live in the same municipality as the proposed TID.

Q: What is the expected termination year? Why is the JRB required to determine this year?
A:
Starting with TIDs that have a 2025 base year, state law (sec. 66.1105(4m)(b)2m. , Wis. Stats.) requires the JRB establish the year it expects the TID to terminate. This year may be different than the TID's statutory maximum life determined by the TID type and when the municipality adopted the creation resolution. When the TID terminates, the TID's actual life compared to the JRB's expected life, based on the expected termination year, determines whether the municipality receives an additional levy adjustment.
Starting with TIDs that have a 2025 base year, state law (sec.
66.1105(4m)(b)2m.
, Wis. Stats.) requires the JRB establish the year it expects the TID to terminate. This year may be different than the TID's statutory maximum life determined by the TID type and when the municipality adopted the creation resolution. When the TID terminates, the TID's actual life compared to the JRB's expected life, based on the expected termination year, determines whether the municipality receives an additional levy adjustment.

Q: What is an expenditure?
A:
The term "expenditure" is found within the definition of "project costs" under state law (sec.
66.1105(2)(f)1.
, Wis. Stats.). "Expenditure" is not defined; however, the Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) considers an expenditure any eligible project cost at the point it is incurred. It does not include repayment of debt for an eligible project cost.

Q: What is the expenditure period?
A:
It is the maximum time period a TID can incur expenses related to the project plan. Generally, it is five years shorter than the maximum life. A municipality cannot take on any new projects after the end of the expenditure period. An extension does not change the expenditure period.
Review the TID Criteria Matrix for the expenditure period by TID type.
It is the maximum time period a TID can incur expenses related to the project plan. Generally, it is five years shorter than the maximum life. A municipality cannot take on any new projects after the end of the expenditure period. An extension does not change the expenditure period.
Example:
A mixed-use TID has a maximum life of 20 years. Because the maximum life is 20 years, the expenditure period is 15 years.
Review the
TID Criteria Matrix
for the expenditure period by TID type.

Q: What date is used to measure the start of the expenditure period?
A: The date the local legislative body adopts the creation resolution is the start of the expenditure period.

Q: Can "new" project costs be incurred after the expenditure period?
A: No. Existing projects may be finished but no additional improvements can be started during the last five years of the TID's maximum life.

Q: What is considered an existing project?
A:
- Project must be documented in the JRB approved project plan, and
- Either the physical project is started, or one of the following must be in place: Established financing for the project​ Signed contract Signed developer's agreement
- Established financing for the project​
- Signed contract
- Signed developer's agreement

and
Either the physical project is started, or one of the following must be in place:

Signed contract

Q: Can payments be made after the expenditure period?
A:
Yes. Payments for project cost debt service, repayment of advances or other liabilities and approved allocations to other TIDs are allowed under state law (sec. 66.1105(6)(c) , Wis. Stats.). Costs for professional services, administration, and DOR fees required to maintain the TID are also allowed.
Yes. Payments for project cost debt service, repayment of advances or other liabilities and approved allocations to other TIDs are allowed under state law (sec.
66.1105(6)(c)
, Wis. Stats.). Costs for professional services, administration, and DOR fees required to maintain the TID are also allowed.

Q: Can a municipality request an extension to a TID's expenditure period?
A: No. State law does not allow extensions to a TID's expenditure period. A municipality must incur project expenditures before the expenditure period ends.

Q: Are there any restrictions on the length of maturity for TID debt?
A: No. The same restrictions for other municipal debt apply to TID debt and would likely not mature beyond the TID's maximum life.

Q: Can a municipality transfer money from another fund into a TID fund and repay itself later?
A: Yes. It can also charge a reasonable interest cost for advances to a TID fund if made after the TID is created.

Q: If a municipality incurs expenses before it creates a Tax Incremental District (TID), can these expenses be recovered?
A:
If a municipality incurs expenses before it creates a TID, the municipality can only recover expenses directly related to planning the district. The municipality cannot incur other expenses until after the municipality adopts the creation resolution approving the project plan. (sec. 66.1105(6)(am)3. , Wis. Stats.)
If a municipality incurs expenses before it creates a TID, the municipality can only recover expenses directly related to planning the district. The municipality cannot incur other expenses until after the municipality adopts the creation resolution approving the project plan. (sec.
66.1105(6)(am)3.
, Wis. Stats.)

Q: What expenses can be considered "planning" expenses?
A: State law does not define planning expenses; however, the consulting, legal, engineering, architectural or administrative costs required to develop and approve the project plan may qualify. The municipality should consult its attorney for assistance to determine if a specific cost is considered a planning expense.

Q: If a municipality purchased property before it creates a TID and sells the property after the TID is approved, can the property purchase be considered a TID expense?
A:
No. The property purchase is not an eligible TID expense. The purchase occurred before the TID was approved and is not a planning expense.
If a municipality purchases property within one year before the TID creation, when setting the TID base value the land must be valued as if the purchase did not occur. (sec. 66.1105(5)(e) , Wis. Stats.)
No. The property purchase is not an eligible TID expense. The purchase occurred before the TID was approved and is not a planning expense.
If a municipality purchases property within one year before the TID creation, when setting the TID base value the land must be valued as if the purchase did not occur. (sec.
66.1105(5)(e)
, Wis. Stats.)

Q: If a municipality purchased property before it creates a TID and sells the land after the TID is approved, can the funds from the sale be returned to the municipality's general fund?
A:
The portion of profits attributed to the TID are "other revenues" under s​ec. 66.1105(2)(f)1. , Wis.  Stats., and must be used to offset project costs. The remainder may be placed in the municipality’s general fund. The municipality should contact its attorney to review how to apply this law to the specific situation.
The portion of profits attributed to the TID are "other revenues" under s​ec.
66.1105(2)(f)1.
, Wis.  Stats., and must be used to offset project costs. The remainder may be placed in the municipality’s general fund. The municipality should contact its attorney to review how to apply this law to the specific situation.

Q: Can a municipality buy and improve property with TIF funds and place revenue from the improved property's sale into the general fund?
A: No. A municipality cannot make a profit with TIF. It must use revenue from the sale of property purchased and improved with TIF funds to offset all other TID project costs.

Q: Can a municipality use TIF funds to reduce special assessments to property owners after the improvements are installed?
A:
No. Reducing special assessments is not a TID eligible expense, under state law (sec. 66.1105(2)(f) , Wis. Stats.). However, a municipality may combine a special assessment and TIF to pay for a particular project. That portion paid for with a special assessment is a non-project cost for the TID.
No. Reducing special assessments is not a TID eligible expense, under state law (sec.
66.1105(2)(f)
, Wis. Stats.). However, a municipality may combine a special assessment and TIF to pay for a particular project. That portion paid for with a special assessment is a non-project cost for the TID.

Q: Is municipal-owned property included in the Tax Incremental District (TID) base value?
A: Since October 1, 2015, municipal-owned property is excluded from the base value, unless the purchase date is within one year before the municipality's TID creation resolution. In that case the property's assessed value before purchase is included in the base value.

Q: Which TID form do we use to enter the municipal-owned property?
A:
Use Form PE-619 to enter the TID's municipal-owned parcel numbers and purchase date for each.  Enter a value when the purchase date was within one year before the municipality's adopted TID creation resolution date. Email this completed form to tif@wisconsin.gov with the other forms in the Base Value Workbook .
Use
Form PE-619
to enter the TID's municipal-owned parcel numbers and purchase date for each.  Enter a value when the purchase date was within one year before the municipality's adopted TID creation resolution date. Email this completed form to tif@wisconsin.gov with the other forms in the
Base Value Workbook
.

Q: Which TID form do we use to enter property owned by another municipality?
A:
- Form PE-619 – list any parcels owned by the municipality creating the TID
- Form PE-608 – list any parcels owned by a different municipality, with the appropriate classification
On the Base Value Workbook:
Form PE-619 – list any parcels owned by the municipality creating the TID
Form PE-608 – list any parcels owned by a different municipality, with the appropriate classification

Q: Should municipal-owned property be valued according to its exempt classification or at its value before it was purchased by the municipality?
A:
- More than a year — if the property was purchased more than a year before the municipality's TID creation resolution, use the current property value, usually "zero"
- ​ Within one year — if the property was purchased within one year before the municipality's TID creation resolution, use the assessed value prior to the purchase

Q: Does a territory addition amendment include the prior year value for municipal property purchased within a year prior to the municipal resolution?
A:
Yes. A territory addition amendment creates a new part of the TID. The same guidelines apply to both a TID's creation and a territory addition amendment.
- More than a year — if the property was purchased more than a year before the municipality's TID creation resolution, use the current property value, usually "zero"
- Within one year — if the property was purchased within one year before the municipality's TID creation resolution, use the assessed value prior to the purchase

if the property was purchased
more than a year
before the municipality's TID creation resolution, use the current property value, usually "zero"
Within one year —
if the property was purchased
within one year
before the municipality's TID creation resolution, use the assessed value prior to the purchase
In both cases, enter the appropriate value and the municipal purchase date on
Form PE-619
of the
Base Value Workbook
.

Q: What if the municipality purchased property within one year before the TID creation but the property was exempt before the purchase? What amount is included in the TID base value?
A:
When the municipal-owned property was exempt before the purchase, no value for the property is included in the TID base. Enter the parcel with exempt classification and a value of zero on Form PE-619 of the Base Value Workbook . It is helpful to provide an explanation why the property was previously exempt (ex: it was owned by the school district or a non-profit entity).
When the municipal-owned property was exempt before the purchase, no value for the property is included in the TID base. Enter the parcel with exempt classification and a value of zero on
Form PE-619
of the
Base Value Workbook
. It is helpful to provide an explanation why the property was previously exempt (ex: it was owned by the school district or a non-profit entity).

Q: In a mixed-use TID, how is municipal-owned exempt property (park/cemetery) included in the calculation when determining the 35% newly-platted residential limitation?
A: To determine the percentage, divide the TID's newly-platted residential property acreage by all real property acreage (including exempt property).

Q: Can a municipality purchase property and then create a TID for that property?
A:
Yes. However, under state law (sec. 66.1105(5)(e) , Wis. Stats.), any property the municipality purchases within one year before the TID's creation must be treated as if the sale did not occur, unless the municipality can prove it acquired the property for a reason other than creating the TID.
Yes. However, under state law (sec.
66.1105(5)(e)
, Wis. Stats.), any property the municipality purchases within one year before the TID's creation must be treated as if the sale did not occur, unless the municipality can prove it acquired the property for a reason other than creating the TID.

Q: What is an overlap?
A:
An overlap is when the boundary of one Tax Incremental District (TID) covers another existing TID's boundaries. For more information, review state law (sec. 66.1105(10) , Wis. Stats.).
An overlap is when the boundary of one Tax Incremental District (TID) covers another existing TID's boundaries. For more information, review state law (sec.
66.1105(10)
, Wis. Stats.).

Q: Does an overlap change the boundary of the overlapped TID?
A: No. The overlapped TID's boundaries are not affected by an overlap. The overlapped TID must still maintain whole parcels.

Q: How are TID values affected by overlapping?
A:
The newest overlapping TID includes the current value in its TID base and will receive future increment value.
The older overlapped TID includes the increment value it received before the overlap, but no longer receives any future increment. The current value of the existing TID before the new overlapping TID was created becomes a frozen overlap value. The Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) establishes the frozen overlap value and includes it in the older TID's total current year value until the TID terminates.
Here is a simplified example:
- TID 1 was created in 2023 with a base value of $150,000
- In 2024, the value for TID 1 is $300,000
- TID 2 is created in 2024 and completely overlaps TID 1 in 2024
- TID 2's base value is $300,000
- The frozen overlap value for TID 1 is $300,000 (the value in the year it was overlapped) This value remains the same for the remainder of TID 1's life
- This value remains the same for the remainder of TID 1's life
- Any property value increase in 2025 or later generates increment value for TID 2
The newest overlapping TID includes the current value in its TID base and will receive future increment value.
The older overlapped TID includes the increment value it received before the overlap, but no longer receives any future increment. The current value of the existing TID before the new overlapping TID was created becomes a frozen overlap value. The Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) establishes the frozen overlap value and includes it in the older TID's total current year value until the TID terminates.
Here is a simplified example:
TID 1 was created in 2023 with a base value of $150,000
In 2024, the value for TID 1 is $300,000
TID 2 is created in 2024 and completely overlaps TID 1 in 2024
TID 2's base value is $300,000
The frozen overlap value for TID 1 is $300,000 (the value in the year it was overlapped)
This value remains the same for the remainder of TID 1's life
Any property value increase in 2025 or later generates increment value for TID 2

Q: How is the overlapped TID's current value calculated?
A:
The current value of overlapped property, at the time it is overlapped, is the frozen overlap value. DOR establishes the frozen overlap value for the overlapped TID.
Example:
- TID 3 is partially overlapped by TID 4
- TID 3's base value does not change
- In the year of the overlap, the current full value of the overlapped property is $10,000
- After DOR certifies TID 4, DOR includes the $10,000 frozen overlap value in TID 3's current value
- DOR adds the $10,000 frozen value to TID 3's current value every year until the TID terminates
- The frozen overlap value will not change Exception:  Additional property in TID 3 is overlapped
- Exception:  Additional property in TID 3 is overlapped
- The current values plus the frozen overlap value equals the total value used to calculate the TID increment (see table below)
- In the below example, the total current year TID 3 value is $275,000 (property value $265,000 plus $10,000 frozen overlap value)
- Current value ($275,000) minus base value ($150,000) equals a TID increment value of $125,000

Q: Where can the municipality view the TID's frozen overlap value?
A:
The municipality can view the value of the frozen overlap on the TID Statement of Changes report.
The municipality can view the value of the frozen overlap on the
TID Statement of Changes
report.

Q: Can the municipality continue paying for projects in the overlapped parcels with increment from the existing TID?
A: Yes. The municipality continues to receive tax increment funds for the overlapped TID to pay its project costs.

Q: Does the Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) use the parcel overlap value in determining the 12% value limit?
A:
No. Under state law (sec. 66.1105(10)(c) , Wis. Stats.), DOR excludes this value from the new TID when determining compliance with the 12% limit. The parcel value is already included in the value increment for the existing TID.
No. Under state law (sec.
66.1105(10)(c)
, Wis. Stats.), DOR excludes this value from the new TID when determining compliance with the 12% limit. The parcel value is already included in the value increment for the existing TID.

Q: For the parcels in the overlapped area, are both the new and old TID number shown on the assessment/tax roll?
A: No. On the assessment/tax roll, the overlapped (older) TID number is removed from the parcel and the overlapping (newer) TID number is added to the parcel. A parcel may only have one TID number on the assessment/tax roll.

Q: If the overlapping (newer) TID terminates and the overlapped (older) TID is still active, should the TID number be changed back to the overlapped TID?
A: No, do not put the older TID back on the overlapped parcels. The overlapped TID receives a frozen overlap value until it terminates. Putting the older TID number on the overlapped parcels may cause an incorrect current value for the overlapped TID.

Q: Will the frozen overlap value of an overlapped TID be deleted if the overlapping TID is terminated?
A: No. Once a frozen overlap value exists for an overlapped TID, the frozen overlap value is included in the current year TID value until the overlapped TID terminates. The frozen overlap value for the overlapped TID does not change even if the overlapping TID terminates.

Q: To subtract overlapped parcels, which TID does a municipality amend? The older TID or the newer TID?
A: To subtract overlapped parcels, the municipality must subtract the parcels from the TID currently shown on the assessment/tax roll. Generally, the newer TID is on the assessment/tax roll.

Q: Is the overlapping TID always the newer TID?
A: Generally, a newer TID overlaps an older TID. However, a municipality may add territory to an older TID that overlaps a newer TID.

Q: Will the frozen overlap value of an overlapped TID be reduced if overlapped parcels are subtracted from the overlapping TID?
A: No. Once a frozen overlap value exists for an overlapped TID, the frozen overlap value is included in the current year TID value until the overlapped TID terminates. The frozen overlap value does not change even if the overlapped parcels are subtracted from the overlapping TID.

Q: If a new TID completely overlaps an existing TID, does the overlapped TID still exist?
A: Yes. The overlapped TID remains active until the municipality adopts a termination resolution. Due to the frozen overlap value, the municipality may continue to receive tax increment.

Q: Can a distressed or severely distressed TID be overlapped by a newly created TID?
A: No. A newly created TID or an active TID that is adding parcels may not overlap a distressed or severely distressed TID.

Q: Can an Environmental Remediation (ER) TID created under sec. 66.1105, Wis. Stats., overlap another TID created under the same section? Or another ER TID created under sec. 66.1106, Wis. Stats.?
A: Yes. An ER TID created under sec. 66.1105, Wis. Stats., can overlap another TID created under the same section or an ER TID created under sec. 66.1106, Wis. Stats.

Q: Can parcels be added to the Tax Incremental District (TID) after the hearing notices are published?
A:
Yes. The purpose of the public hearing is to receive/give input on the proposed boundaries of the district.  A municipality may add or remove parcels based on the hearing.  The hearing notice does not have to mention the proposed boundaries; however, including a general description of the area is helpful.
Yes. The purpose of the public hearing is to receive/give input on the
proposed
boundaries of the district.  A municipality may add or remove parcels based on the hearing.  The hearing notice does not have to mention the proposed boundaries; however, including a general description of the area is helpful.

Q: How much detail is needed in the boundary description provided to the Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR)?
A:
A metes and bounds (legal boundary) description corresponding to the outer TID boundary is required. The boundary description must match the provided map.
See TID Checklist , Boundary and Map section.
A metes and bounds (legal boundary) description corresponding to the outer TID boundary is required. The boundary description must match the provided map.
See
TID Checklist
, Boundary and Map section.

Q: Why is a boundary description required in addition to the map?
A:
State law (sec. 66.1105(4)(gm)1. , Wis. Stats.), requires the local legislative body to describe the TID boundaries. A metes and bounds description is necessary because parcel numbers and parcel boundaries may change over the TID's life.
State law (sec.
66.1105(4)(gm)1.
, Wis. Stats.), requires the local legislative body to describe the TID boundaries. A metes and bounds description is necessary because parcel numbers and parcel boundaries may change over the TID's life.

Q: How much detail is needed in the TID map provided to DOR?
A:
Map must be legible and:
Note:
- Show the outer boundary of the TID
- Show each parcel boundary
- Label each parcel by tax number or designate a map identification number
- Label all areas that do not have a parcel number (ex: streets, railroads, wetlands, or bodies of water)
- Label the municipality or county boundaries if within the map view
- Indicate the municipality name and TID number
- Show the boundaries of the overlapped TID, when overlapping exists
- Each numbered parcel on the map must be listed on the Base Value Workbook Exception: Do not list road or railroad parcels with a parcel number that are only partially in the TID boundary
- Exception: Do not list road or railroad parcels with a parcel number that are only partially in the TID boundary
- Provide additional enlarged areas of the map, where boundaries or parcel numbers are too small to see clearly even when magnified
- For a territory amendment - show the original TID area, added/subtracted parcels and updated boundary

Q: Who is responsible for valuing and classifying a TID's land and buildings?
A: The local assessor and DOR manufacturing assessor are responsible for valuing the improvements and land based on state law and the Wisconsin Property Assessment Manual.

Q: A TID must contain contiguous properties; however, can a municipality omit parcels from the TID's center?
A: Yes. A municipality may omit parcels, as long as the TID boundaries remain contiguous. The TID map must clearly show the parcels are not part of the TID.  The legal description must be consistent with the map and describe the excluded area.​

Q: When two parcels are diagonal (kitty corner) from each other, is this contiguous?
A: Yes. Two parcels that are diagonal to each other are considered contiguous and can be included in the same TID. They may or may not have a road or railroad between them.

Q: If the TID crosses a highway, river or railroad track, is this contiguous?
A:
Yes. This is contiguous if the highway, river or railroad tracks are continuously bounded on either side or both sides by TID parcels. A highway, river or railroad tracks alone cannot create contiguity.
Railroad tracks, regardless of ownership, must be bounded by TID parcels.

Q: What is the difference between railroad tracks and a railroad right-of-way?
A: There is no difference. Railroad tracks cannot create contiguity in a TID. The railroad tracks must be bounded on either side or both sides by TID parcels.

Q: How do we handle a road or railroad with a parcel number when completing the Base Value Workbook?
A:
DOR treats roads and railroads the same way. If the road or railroad parcel is completely within the TID boundary, list the parcel number on the map and the value forms. If the road or railroad parcel is partially in the TID boundary, identify the road or railroad on the map and do not list the parcel number on the value forms.
DOR treats roads and railroads the same way. If the road or railroad parcel is
completely
within the TID boundary, list the parcel number on the map and the value forms. If the road or railroad parcel is partially in the TID boundary, identify the road or railroad on the map and do not list the parcel number on the value forms.

Q: Can a parcel (exempt or non-exempt) be partly in a TID?
A:
No. Under state law (sec. 66.1105(2)(k) , Wis. Stats.), only whole parcels can be in a TID. Roads and railroads are an exception. Roads/railroads can only be included in a TID where they are bounded by TID parcels, whether they have a parcel number or not.
No. Under state law (sec.
66.1105(2)(k)
, Wis. Stats.), only whole parcels can be in a TID. Roads and railroads are an exception. Roads/railroads can only be included in a TID where they are bounded by TID parcels, whether they have a parcel number or not.

Q: How can a municipality combine two parcels if one parcel is in the TID and the other parcel is outside the TID?
A:
A TID must contain whole parcels. To combine parcels inside and outside the TID, a municipality must complete one of the following amendments:
- Territory addition amendment — add the parcel that is out of the TID to the TID area. Its value is added to the TID base value.
- Territory subtraction amendment — remove the existing parcel from the TID area. Its value is subtracted from the TID base value.
A TID must contain whole parcels. To combine parcels inside and outside the TID, a municipality must complete one of the following amendments:
Territory addition amendment
—
add the parcel that is out of the TID to the TID area. Its value is added to the TID base value.
Territory subtraction amendment
—
remove the existing parcel from the TID area. Its value is subtracted from the TID base value.

Q: If property owned by a utility company is included in a TID, is the property exempt?
A:
Location of a property in a TID does not determine taxability. Generally, utility property is not subject to local taxation and pays a state tax. Contact DOR's Manufacturing and Utility Bureau for more information. Tax exempt property in a TID does not add to the base value and does not contribute to the value increment.
Location of a property in a TID does not determine taxability. Generally, utility property is not subject to local taxation and pays a state tax. Contact DOR's
Manufacturing and Utility Bureau
for more information. Tax exempt property in a TID does not add to the base value and does not contribute to the value increment.

Q: How should a municipality indicate that wetlands are excluded from the TID?
A: The municipality may describe the boundaries around the wetland, or state that all wetlands are excluded at the end of the TID boundary's legal description.

Q: Can wetlands be used to make a TID contiguous?
A:
Wetlands identified on a map under sec. 23.32 , Wis. Stats., must be excluded from a TID. When an entire parcel meets this definition of wetlands, it cannot be included in the TID.
When only part of the parcel is wetland, the parcel can be used to establish TID contiguity. When planning a TID, consider requesting DOR review the map.
Wetlands identified on a map under sec.
23.32
, Wis. Stats., must be excluded from a TID. When an entire parcel meets this definition of wetlands, it cannot be included in the TID.
When only part of the parcel is wetland, the parcel can be used to establish TID contiguity. When planning a TID, consider requesting DOR review the map.

Q: What are "lands proposed for newly platted residential use?"
A:
State law does not define the phrase "lands proposed for newly platted residential use." A "plat" is a map of a subdivision. "Newly platted" refers to land that has not been previously subdivided or is currently subject to a replat as defined in sec. 236.02(11) , Wis. Stats. "Residential" commonly means relating to a place where people live.
When reviewing a project plan, DOR considers the current use, or zoning, and the future use, or zoning, as indicators of whether an area consists of "lands proposed for newly platted residential use." The plan should specify the parcels proposed for newly platted residential development.
Example of lands proposed for newly platted residential use: When residential lots are platted on an undeveloped parcel of land, such as subdividing a farm field for housing.

236.02(11)
, Wis. Stats. "Residential" commonly means relating to a place where people live.

Example of lands proposed for newly platted residential use:
When residential lots are platted on an undeveloped parcel of land, such as subdividing a farm field for housing.

Q: What TID types can include costs for lands proposed for newly platted residential property?
A:
Only TIDs declared as mixed-use type can incur project costs for lands proposed for newly platted residential property; the property may not exceed 35 percent by area of the TID.
Under state law (sec. 66.1105(2)(f)3. , Wis. Stats.), a municipality may only spend increment revenue on newly platted residential development in mixed-use TIDs if one of the following applies:
- Density of the residential housing is at least three units per acre;
- Residential housing is located in a conservation subdivision, as defined in sec. 66.1027(1)(a) , Wis. Stats.
- Residential housing is located in a traditional neighborhood development, as defined in sec. 66.1027(1)(c) , Wis. Stats.

Residential housing is located in a conservation subdivision, as defined in sec.
66.1027(1)(a)
, Wis. Stats.
Residential housing is located in a traditional neighborhood development, as defined in sec.
66.1027(1)(c)
, Wis. Stats.

Q: How is a road/highway included in the calculation determining the 35% residential use in mixed-use TIDs?
A: Include road/highway acreage in the total TID acreage but not the residential acreage. Divide the newly platted residential acreage, not including roads, by the total TID acreage to determine the newly platted residential percentage.

Q: In a mixed-use TID, does the housing density calculation include roads and parks?
A:
No. The housing density is based on all real property in the area designated as residential . This does not include roads or greenspace, but does include all housing whether subject to property tax or exempt.
No. The housing density is based on all real property in the area designated as
residential
. This does not include roads or greenspace, but does include all housing whether subject to property tax or exempt.

Q: For the 35% limit on lands proposed for newly platted residential use, is an assisted living building considered a residential use? Is multi-family housing?
A: Yes. Both an assisted living building and multi-family housing are considered residential use because the buildings are used for living purposes. The property still needs to be newly platted as part of the TID project plan to be subject to the 35% limit. This assumes that current or future zoning permits the assisted living or multi-family building.

Q: Can a TID's boundaries be set based on something that will happen in the future?
A: No. The boundaries are determined based on the parcels when the TID is created. Territory amendments are possible to address parcel combinations, splits or annexations.

Q: Do projects within a TID have to follow local zoning?
A: Yes. TIF law does not change municipal zoning rules.

Q: For mixed-use TIDs, does the land need to be zoned correctly before adopting the creation resolution?
A:
No. The municipality does not need to complete zoning before it adopts the creation resolution. At least 50% of the land must be suitable (not necessarily zoned) for at least two of the following types: industrial, commercial or residential. There are no restrictions on the percentage between the types.
No. The municipality does not need to complete zoning before it adopts the creation resolution. At least 50% of the land must be
suitable
(not necessarily zoned) for at least two of the following types: industrial, commercial or residential. There are no restrictions on the percentage between the types.

Q: In an industrial TID, do all the parcels need to be zoned industrial?
A:
No. To qualify as an industrial TID, at least 50% (by area) must be zoned industrial. Under state law (sec. 66.1105(4)(gm)5. , Wis. Stats.), the parcels that are zoned industrial when the TID is created (municipal resolution adoption date) must remain zoned industrial for the life of the TID.
No. To qualify as an industrial TID, at least 50% (by area) must be zoned industrial. Under state law (sec.
66.1105(4)(gm)5.
, Wis. Stats.), the parcels that are zoned industrial when the TID is created (municipal resolution adoption date) must remain zoned industrial for the life of the TID.

Q: What are eligible project costs?
A:
Eligible project costs are those costs related directly to establishing and improving the Tax Incremental District (TID), including:
- Capital development
- Financing
- Professional services (ex: consulting, accounting, legal services)
- Organizational and administrative activities
- Annual fees
- Relocation
- Creation of TID maps or architectural drawings
- Utility or street construction directly associated with the TID
- Removal or containment of lead contamination
- Demolition or building repairs
- Developer incentive (if municipality signs an agreement with the developer)
Eligible project costs are those costs related directly to establishing and improving the Tax Incremental District (TID), including:
Capital development
Financing
Professional services (ex: consulting, accounting, legal services)
Organizational and administrative activities
Annual fees
Relocation
TID project cost examples:
Creation of TID maps or architectural drawings
Utility or street construction directly associated with the TID
Removal or containment of lead contamination
Demolition or building repairs
Developer incentive (if municipality signs an agreement with the developer)
Under state law (sec.
66.1105(2)(f)1.k.
), improvements outside the TID may be eligible costs, but only to the extent that the improvement serves property in the TID (ex: water or sewage lines, treatment plants, and water towers).

Q: Are project costs for an Environmental Remediation (ER) type TID limited to costs for remediating the environmental pollution?
A:
No. The same list of eligible costs applies to an ER TID created after November 29, 2017, and other TID types created under sec. 66.1105, Wis. Stats.  Review sec. 66.1105(2)(f)1. , Wis. Stats. for more information.
No. The same list of eligible costs applies to an ER TID created after November 29, 2017, and other TID types created under sec. 66.1105, Wis. Stats.  Review sec.
66.1105(2)(f)1.
, Wis. Stats. for more information.

Q: Do eligible costs include capitalized interest, other costs of issuing debt, and refinancing temporary debt for the Tax Incremental District (TID)?
A:
Yes. These are eligible financing costs authorized in sec. 66.1105(2)(f)1.b. , Wis. Stats.
Yes. These are eligible financing costs authorized in sec.
66.1105(2)(f)1.b.
, Wis. Stats.

Q: Who determines if project costs are eligible?
A:
It is the municipality's responsibility to determine if a project cost is eligible under state law (sec. 66.1105(2)(f)1. & 2. , Wis. Stats.). The municipality should consult its attorney for assistance on whether a specific cost is eligible. The Wisconsin Department of Revenue does not review project costs or determine cost eligibility.
It is the municipality's responsibility to determine if a project cost is eligible under state law (sec.
66.1105(2)(f)1. & 2.
, Wis. Stats.). The municipality should consult its attorney for assistance on whether a specific cost is eligible. The Wisconsin Department of Revenue does not review project costs or determine cost eligibility.

Q: Can a municipality reduce the costs of one project in a plan and use that amount for another project not in the plan?
A: No. However, the municipality may shift TIF funds to a new project if the municipality completes a project plan amendment to include the additional project.

Q: Can a municipality add projects without adding territory?
A:
Yes. This is possible if the municipality completes a project plan amendment to add projects. Review the TIF Project Plan Amendments web page.
Yes. This is possible if the municipality completes a project plan amendment to add projects. Review the TIF
Project Plan Amendments
web page.

Q: For mixed-use TIDs, are there restrictions on the project costs' percentage?
A: No. The costs for each area do not need to match the land type percentages. For example, a mixed-use TID may contain 90% ​of the project costs for industrial projects and 10% for commercial projects even though 10% of the land is industrial, and 90% is commercial.

Q: What are non-project costs?
A:
Non-project costs are expenses that are not eligible to be paid with TIF funds or public works projects that only partly benefit the TID. A municipality cannot use tax increments to pay these costs.
- Public improvement made: Within the TID – that also benefits property outside the TID. The portion of the total project costs allocated to the properties outside the TID is a non-project cost. Outside the TID – that also benefits property within the TID. The portion of the total project costs allocated to the properties outside the TID is a non-project cost.
- Within the TID – that also benefits property outside the TID. The portion of the total project costs allocated to the properties outside the TID is a non-project cost.
- Outside the TID – that also benefits property within the TID. The portion of the total project costs allocated to the properties outside the TID is a non-project cost.
- That portion of projects within the TID as part of the project plan implementation that are paid by user​ fees, grants, special assessments or revenues other than TIF increments
- Project costs for construction or expansion of administrative buildings and general government operating expenses unrelated to the TID

Project costs for construction or expansion of administrative buildings and general government operating expenses unrelated to the TID

Q: Can a municipality include projects within a half-mile radius of the TID?
A: Yes. A municipality may include projects outside the TID but within a half-mile radius if the projects are documented in the approved project plan. Only eligible costs within the half-mile radius can be paid for with TIF funds.

Q: How is the half-mile radius determined? Is it measured from the TID's center or the outer boundary?
A: The half-mile radius is measured from the TID's outer boundary.

Q: Can the municipality include projects within the TID's half-mile radius but outside the municipal boundary?
A:
No, projects outside the TID must be within the municipal boundary (sec. 66.1105(2)(f)1.n. , Wis. Stats.).
- Within a half-mile of existing TID boundary
- Within municipal limits
- Eligible TIF expenditure
- Detailed in the project plan
- Approved by the JRB, as part of the TID creation or amendment process
No, projects outside the TID must be within the municipal boundary (sec.
66.1105(2)(f)1.n.
, Wis. Stats.).
Projects outside the TID must be:
Within a half-mile of existing TID boundary
Within municipal limits
Eligible TIF expenditure
Detailed in the project plan
Approved by the JRB, as part of the TID creation or amendment process

Q: Is a property tax refund an eligible TID project cost?
A: No. A property tax refund is not an eligible TID project cost and is not included as an approved cost in the project plan.

Q: Does the municipality need to amend the project plan if the costs change, but the projects don't change?
A:
No. Usually the project costs in the plan are estimates and may change over time due to inflation, supply, or other factors.
No. Usually the project costs in the plan are estimates and may change over time due to inflation, supply, or other factors.
​ H​owever, when the planned projects change, the municipality must amend the project plan.

Q: Does a municipality need to complete all projects in the plan?
A: No. The project plan is a capital improvement plan (not an approved budget), therefore a municipality does not have to complete all projects. The municipality decides when and which project to complete. Many municipalities start individual projects as the funds become available (pay-as-you-go).

Q: Are there any projects outside the Tax Incremental District (TID) that can be paid with tax increments?
A:
Yes. The municipality may pay for projects within a half-mile radius of the TID if they are documented in the project plan and approved by the Joint Review Board. For more information, review state law (sec. 66.1105(2)(f)1.n. , Wis. Stats.).
Also, the municipality may pay for a proportionate share of public improvements outside the TID with tax increments if the improvement serves property in the TID (ex: water tower, water or sewage lines, treatment plants). For more information, review state law (sec. 66.1105(2)(f)1.k. , Wis. Stats.).
Yes. The municipality may pay for projects within a half-mile radius of the TID if they are documented in the project plan and approved by the Joint Review Board. For more information, review state law (sec.
66.1105(2)(f)1.n.
, Wis. Stats.).
Also, the municipality may pay for a proportionate share of public improvements outside the TID with tax increments if the improvement serves property in the TID (ex: water tower, water or sewage lines, treatment plants). For more information, review state law (sec.
66.1105(2)(f)1.k.
, Wis. Stats.).

Q: Does a municipality need to amend a project plan if an unanticipated development occurs?
A: It depends on whether the development requires changes to the TID's planned projects. When a municipality wants to change the planned projects to support the new development, it must amend the plan.

Q: How long does it take to amend a project plan?
A:
It depends on how long it takes the municipality to assemble the information and hold the necessary meetings. Generally, it takes less time than creating a new TID because only one hearing notice is required and there is no required waiting period between the public hearing and the municipal resolution.
See the Tax Incremental District (TID) Checklist.
It depends on how long it takes the municipality to assemble the information and hold the necessary meetings. Generally, it takes less time than creating a new TID because only one hearing notice is required and there is no required waiting period between the public hearing and the municipal resolution.
See the
Tax Incremental District (TID) Checklist.

Q: If a municipality amends a project plan, can the municipality incur costs for a newly platted residential development?
A:
A municipality may only incur costs for a newly platted residential development for a mixed-use type TID.
See Parcels question 17 for additional information on development types allowed.
A municipality may only incur costs for a newly platted residential development for a mixed-use type TID.
See
Parcels question 17
for additional information on development types allowed.

Q: Does a municipality need to conduct a new economic feasibility study when it amends a project plan?
A:
Yes. If a municipality amends the plan, it must update the economic feasibility study in the project plan. See Guidelines for Project Plans .
Yes. If a municipality amends the plan, it must update the economic feasibility study in the project plan. See
Guidelines for Project Plans
.

Q: If development not supported by TIF occurs, does the municipality need to amend the plan because this will change the economic feasibility study?
A: Any development in the TID, whether supported by TIF or not, generates increment the municipality can use to pay project costs. An increment increase could allow the municipality to pay costs sooner than anticipated in the plan's economic feasibility study. However, the municipality does not need to amend the plan solely to revise the economic feasibility study.

Q: Can the municipality add projects or costs to the plan after the public hearing notice is published?
A: Yes. The municipality may revise the project plan and costs any time before adopting the municipal resolution. The Joint Review Board must adopt a resolution approving the final project plan.

Q: When can the municipality begin projects added to an amended project plan?
A: Except for planning costs, the municipality must complete the project plan amendment before using tax increments to pay for projects not in the project plan.

Q: How many days before the public hearing does a municipality need to publish a Class 1 notice? A Class 2 notice?
A:
When creating a TID — the municipality must publish a Class 2 notice in the newspaper for the public hearing. The Class 2 notice must be published once each week for two consecutive weeks with the last notice published at least seven days before the public hearing.
When amending a TID — the municipality must publish a Class 1 notice in the newspaper at least seven days before the public hearing
When creating a TID —
the municipality must publish a Class 2 notice in the newspaper for the public hearing. The Class 2 notice must be published once each week for two consecutive weeks with the last notice published at least seven days before the public hearing.
When amending a TID —
the municipality must publish a Class 1 notice in the newspaper at least seven days before the public hearing

Q: What must be included in a public notice?
A:
The meeting notice must inform the public of the time, date, place, and subject matter of the meeting. A TID amendment notice must also include the purpose and cost of the amendment.
For assistance, see the sample notices on the TIF Public Notices web page.
The meeting notice must inform the public of the time, date, place, and subject matter of the meeting. A TID amendment notice must also include the purpose and cost of the amendment.
For assistance, see the sample notices on the TIF
Public Notices
web page.

Q: Does the public hearing notice need to include a description of the proposed Tax Incremental District's (TID) outer boundary?
A: No. Under state law, the hearing notices do not have to include a legal description or parcel numbers; however, it may be helpful to include a small map or street locations to describe the area in the TID.

Q: Does the public hearing notice need to include a list of the TID projects and costs?
A:
For a TID creation, the notice should include a description of the planned projects but does not need to include individual costs.
For any TID amendment, the notice must include both the purpose and the total cost of the amendment (sec. 66.1105(4)(h)1. , Wis. Stats). ​Include in the cost, any additional eligible project costs such as capital development, financing, professional services, or allocations to another TID.
For a TID creation, the notice should include a description of the planned projects but does not need to include individual costs.
For any TID amendment, the notice must include both the purpose and the total cost of the amendment (sec.
66.1105(4)(h)1.
, Wis. Stats). ​Include in the cost, any additional eligible project costs such as capital development, financing, professional services, or allocations to another TID.

Q: If a TID amendment does not change the TID costs, what should the municipality put in the public hearing notice?
A: If a TID amendment does not change the costs, say this in the public hearing notice.

Q: When a proposed TID overlaps an existing TID, does the public hearing notice need to include this information?
A: No, the public hearing notice does not need to state that the proposed TID overlaps an existing TID, however the municipality may choose to include this information.

Q: How and when must a municipality notify owners of blighted or rehabilitation/conservation property of the public hearing?
A:
Under state law (sec. 66.1105(4)(c) , Wis. Stats.), when creating a TID, a municipality must notify owners of property in the proposed TID that is identified as blighted or in need of rehabilitation/conservation work, at least 15 days before the public hearing.
When adding parcels to an existing TID, a municipality must notify the owners of additional property identified as blighted or in need of rehabilitation/conservation work, at least 15 days before the public hearing.
The law does not specify how to provide the notification; however, sending by mail is the usual method.
Under state law (sec.
66.1105(4)(c)
, Wis. Stats.), when creating a TID, a municipality must notify owners of property in the proposed TID that is identified as blighted or in need of rehabilitation/conservation work, at least 15 days before the public hearing.
When adding parcels to an existing TID, a municipality must notify the owners of
additional
property identified as blighted or in need of rehabilitation/conservation work, at least 15 days before the public hearing.
The law does not specify how to provide the notification; however, sending by mail is the usual method.

Q: Is notification still required if the municipality owns the property identified as blighted or rehabilitation/conservation?
A: Yes. State law requires notification to all owners. The municipality should document the notice by creating a letter in the same format it notifies other owners. This letter does not need to be mailed; however, it must be retained in the municipal TID files.

Q: When a proposed TID is being created, do the adjoining parcel owners receive notification?
A:
State law does not require the municipality to send letters notifying property owners outside a proposed TID boundary. However, the municipality must publish notices for the public hearing and Joint Review Board (JRB) meetings in a local newspaper.
After the TID is created, any property development within the TID follows the approved project plan. If the plan requires changes to zoning, ordinances, or the city's master plan, then the municipality's procedures for making these changes apply.
State law does not require the municipality to send letters notifying property owners outside a proposed TID boundary. However, the municipality must publish notices for the public hearing and Joint Review Board (JRB) meetings in a local newspaper.
After the TID is created, any property development within the TID follows the approved project plan.
If
the plan requires changes to zoning, ordinances, or the city's master plan, then the municipality's procedures for making these changes apply.

Q: Which taxing jurisdictions does a municipality need to notify of the public hearing?
A:
The municipality must provide the public hearing notice to all overlying taxing jurisdictions with the power to levy taxes within the proposed TID, even if the taxing jurisdiction does not have a representative on the JRB.
A special taxing district or a school district/county without the majority value in the TID does not have a representative on the JRB. However, the municipality must still provide those jurisdictions the public hearing notice before it is published.

Q: How does the municipality notify the overlying taxing jurisdictions of the public hearing?
A:
Before January 1, 2025 - under sec. 66.1105(4)(e) , Wis. Stats., the municipality must send, by first class mail, the public hearing notice for a TID creation or amendment to the chief executive officer or administrator of all taxing jurisdictions with the power to levy taxes on property in the proposed TID.
Starting January 1, 2025 - state law does not define the distribution method for municipal TIDs. For town TIDs created under sec. 60.85 Wis. Stats., the town must send, by first class mail, the public hearing notice for a TID creation or amendment to the chief executive officer or administrator of all taxing jurisdictions with the power to levy taxes on property in the proposed TID.
The municipality must provide the overlying taxing jurisdictions the public hearing notice before the notice is published and submit documentation to DOR showing this requirement was met.
Before January 1, 2025 -
under sec.
66.1105(4)(e)
, Wis. Stats., the municipality must send, by first class mail, the public hearing notice for a TID creation or amendment to the chief executive officer or administrator of all taxing jurisdictions with the power to levy taxes on property in the proposed TID.
Starting January 1, 2025 -
state law does not define the distribution method for municipal TIDs. For town TIDs created under sec. 60.85 Wis. Stats., the town must send, by first class mail, the public hearing notice for a TID creation or amendment to the chief executive officer or administrator of all taxing jurisdictions with the power to levy taxes on property in the proposed TID.
The municipality must provide the overlying taxing jurisdictions the public hearing notice before the notice is published and submit documentation to DOR showing this requirement was met.

Q: How does a municipality know what districts exist for the parcels in the TID?
A:
The municipality should contact its assessor for this information. Review Taxation Districts with Underlying Taxing Jurisdictions for information on all existing taxation districts within each municipality.
The municipality should contact its assessor for this information. Review
Taxation Districts with Underlying Taxing Jurisdictions
for information on all existing taxation districts within each municipality.

Q: Does the municipality need to notify a special district that does not levy taxes?
A: The municipality  must notify any special district with the power to levy taxes, even if the district chooses not to levy taxes.

Q: When does a municipality need to publish the Joint Review Board's (JRB) Class 1 notice?
A:
A municipality must publish a Class 1 notice in a local newspaper at least five days before all JRB meetings. (sec. 66.1105(4m)(e) , Wis. Stats.). This includes JRB meetings to discuss TID creations, amendments, extensions, and the TID annual report review meeting.
A municipality must publish a Class 1 notice in a local newspaper at least five days before all JRB meetings. (sec.
66.1105(4m)(e)
, Wis. Stats.). This includes JRB meetings to discuss TID creations, amendments, extensions, and the TID annual report review meeting.

Q: Can a municipality amend a TID plan without holding a public hearing?
A:
No. State law (sec. 66.1105(4)(h)1. , Wis. Stats.), describes the amendment process and requires a public hearing.
No. State law (sec.
66.1105(4)(h)1.
, Wis. Stats.), describes the amendment process and requires a public hearing.

Q: If a municipality is amending a TID, is there a 14-day waiting period between the public hearing and the local legislative body approval?
A: No. The 14-day waiting period is only required when creating a TID; it does not apply to amending a TID. When amending a TID, the municipality can hold the public hearing and adopt a resolution approving the amendment on the same day.

Q: If a municipality previously held a public hearing and JRB organizational meeting, but afterwards put a hold on creating a TID until a few years later, does the municipality need to hold another public hearing and JRB organizational meeting?
A:
Under state law, there is no time limit between the public hearing/JRB's organizational meeting and adoption of the creation resolution. There is only the 14-day waiting period before adopting a resolution.
While not required, it may be best for the municipality to start the process over. This promotes transparency and allows for updates to the project plan. The previous project plan, expenses and goals may no longer apply.

Q: Are the boundary TID type and plan described in the public hearing notice final?
A: No. The public hearing may result in possible changes to the boundary, TID type or project plan. The municipal resolution determines the TID's final details.

Q: For a TID amendment, are the costs described in the public hearing notice final?
A: No. The municipality may make changes to the plan, including costs, after the public hearing. The municipality adopts a resolution to approve the final project plan.

Q: Does posting the public hearing or JRB notice at city hall meet TID requirements for notifying the public?
A: No. State law requires publishing the notice in a local newspaper.

Q: What documents must a municipality provide DOR to demonstrate the notices were published correctly?
A: The municipality must provide a signed affidavit from the newspaper that confirms the publication dates and includes a copy of the actual notice. Sales receipts are not acceptable documentation of the publication dates.

Q: What is the difference between a value increment and a tax increment?
A:
Value increment – difference between the Tax Incremental District's (TID's) base value and current value. It is the property value that generates the tax increment.
Tax increment – taxes levied by all overlying taxing jurisdictions on the value between the TID's base value and current value. The municipality that maintains the TID receives the taxes and must use the funds to pay for the approved project costs.
Value increment –
difference between the Tax Incremental District's (TID's) base value and current value. It is the property value that generates the tax increment.
Tax increment –
taxes levied by all overlying taxing jurisdictions on the value between the TID's base value and current value. The municipality that maintains the TID receives the taxes and must use the funds to pay for the approved project costs.

Q: Who certifies the value increment annually?
A: The Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) certifies the annual value increment by August 15 each year. DOR certifies the increment only if the municipality pays a $150 administrative fee for each active TID by April 15. If the fee is not paid, DOR will not certify the municipality's increment for that year.

Q: When does the municipality receive its first tax increment on a new creation?
A:
The date the municipality adopts the creation resolution determines when it will receive its first increment. The TID Creation Timeframes table explains the timing of the first tax increment.
The date the municipality adopts the creation resolution determines when it will receive its first increment. The
TID Creation Timeframes
table explains the timing of the first tax increment.

Q: Does residential development in a TID produce value increment?
A: Yes. All taxable property that increases a TID's value becomes part of the increment.

Q: If personal property is located within a TID, is the personal property value included in the TID base value? In the TID current value?
A:
2023 Act 12 exempted personal property from taxation, effective January 1, 2024. Starting in 2024, a TID’s current year value does not include personal property.
TIDs created in 2023 and before include taxable personal property in the base value. A municipality may request DOR remove the personal property value from a TID’s base value. Email the Personal Property Adjustment Workbook to tif@wisconsin.gov. DOR will review and adjust the base value. For more information review the TIF Base Value Adjustment due to Personal Property Exemption web page.
TIDs created in 2024 and later do not include personal property in the base value.
2023 Act 12 exempted personal property from taxation, effective January 1, 2024. Starting in 2024, a TID’s current year value does not include personal property.
TIDs created in 2023 and before include taxable personal property in the base value. A municipality may request DOR remove the personal property value from a TID’s base value. Email the Personal Property Adjustment Workbook to tif@wisconsin.gov. DOR will review and adjust the base value. For more information review the
TIF Base Value Adjustment due to Personal Property Exemption
web page.
TIDs created in 2024 and later do not include personal property in the base value.

Q: If a municipality received enough increment to pay the debt incurred for the district, can the excess increment be used for additional projects?
A: Yes. A municipality may use excess increment for additional projects if the expenditure period has not expired; however, only projects in the approved plan may be paid with TIF funds. If the project is not in the approved plan, the municipality must complete a project plan amendment and email the required documents to tif@wisconsin.gov.

Q: If a TID terminates after April 15, is an increment still added to the tax levies in December?
A:
Yes. If the municipality terminates a TID after April 15, DOR will certify a value increment for that year. The tax increment for that year must be levied and collected. See the TID Termination Timeframes table for more information.
Yes. If the municipality terminates a TID after April 15, DOR will certify a value increment for that year. The tax increment for that year must be levied and collected. See the
TID Termination Timeframes
table for more information.

Q: Should a municipality collect the entire final tax increment in the TID's last year if it is not all needed?
A:
Yes. A municipality must collect the entire final tax increment to maintain equal taxation. State law (sec 66.1105(6)(c) , Wis. Stats.), requires the municipality to return any surplus to the TID's overlying taxing jurisdictions.
Yes. A municipality must collect the entire final tax increment to maintain equal taxation. State law (sec
66.1105(6)(c)
, Wis. Stats.), requires the municipality to return any surplus to the TID's overlying taxing jurisdictions.

Q: Can a municipality choose not to levy the increment on the tax roll?
A: No. Wisconsin's constitution has a uniformity clause, which requires uniform property taxation. By not levying the increment, the taxpayers in that municipality would be taxed at a different rate (for school, technical college, or county) than the other taxpayers.

Q: How is the tax increment calculated using the tax rate?
A:
Step a) First, a municipality must determine the tax rate per $1,000 of property value.
Example: The tax rate is $23.73. This amount is then apportioned to the taxing jurisdictions for that municipality.
Step b) Multiply the tax rate by the value increment DOR certifies to determine the actual dollars available to pay eligible project costs.
Example: This is a TID with a 2020 creation year. Changes to the increment value or tax rate result in a different tax increment.
Every municipality with a TID must complete the Tax Increment Worksheet ( Form PC-202 ) each December to calculate the actual tax increment based on the municipality's levy amount. See the detailed example in the TIF Manual, How TIF Works .

Q: How does the Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) notify a municipality of its increment value?
A:
Each year (on August 15 and October 1), DOR posts TIF reports that list each TID's value increment to our website.
Posted reports:
- Apportionment of County Levy (August 15)
- TIF Value Limitation (August 15)
- Statement of Changes (August 15)
- Certification Report (October 1)
