Q: How long are DOR reports available?
A: DOR maintains statewide TID reports for 7 years. All available reports are posted on our website. It is the municipality's responsibility to save information on its TIDs.

Q: When does a municipality terminate a Tax Incremental District (TID)?
A:
The municipality must adopt a termination resolution when one of the following occurs:
- All project costs have been recovered
- TID reaches its maximum life or extended life date
- Municipality decides to terminate the TID early for any other reason
The municipality must adopt a termination resolution when one of the following occurs:
All project costs have been recovered
TID reaches its maximum life or extended life date
Municipality decides to terminate the TID early for any other reason

Q: When filling out the Final TID Accounting Submission Date Agreement (Form PE-223), how does the municipal clerk determine the Final Accounting Submission date?
A: The Final Accounting Submission Date is the date when the municipality agrees to file the TID Final Accounting Report (PE-110). Before submitting this report, the municipality's Certified Public Accountant must complete the final audit. Contact the municipal accountant to determine when the final audit will be completed. Then complete the Final Accounting Submission Date. This due date must be within a year of the TID termination resolution.

Q: What is the last year a municipality receives an increment for a terminated TID?
A:
The date the municipality adopts the termination resolution determines the last year it receives an increment for that TID. For more details see the TID Termination Timeframes table.
The date the municipality adopts the termination resolution determines the last year it receives an increment for that TID. For more details see the
TID Termination Timeframes
table.

Q: If a municipality adopts a TID termination resolution, does the municipality need to pay DOR an administrative fee?
A:
The answer depends on the date the local legislative body adopts the termination resolution:
- On or before April 15 — municipality does not pay the administrative fee that year
- After April 15 — municipality must pay the administrative fee that year
The answer depends on the date the local legislative body adopts the termination resolution:

municipality does not pay the administrative fee that year
After April 15 —
municipality must pay the administrative fee that year

Q: Can a municipality terminate an existing TID and then create another TID in the same year?
A:
Yes.
- Local legislative body must adopt the termination resolution before adopting the creation resolution for another TID
- Municipality must remain below the 12% value limit after terminating a TID, to create another TID
- Local legislative body can adopt a creation resolution for a new TID if the municipality remains below the 12% value limit (including the new TID)
- Termination resolution for an existing TID can occur at any time in the same year

Q: When a municipality terminates a TID, what happens if there are still debts?
A: The municipality is responsible for any remaining debt.

Q: How does the municipality divide excess funds among the overlying taxing jurisdictions?
A:
According to state law (sec. 66.1105(6)(c) , Wis. Stats.), the municipality must return excess funds based on each taxing jurisdiction's portion of the total tax rate. DOR recommends basing the distribution on the most recent tax levy proportions without the tax increment. Column A of the Tax Increment Worksheet (PC-202) may be used for this calculation. Contact lgs@wisconsin.gov for further assistance.
According to state law (sec.
66.1105(6)(c)
, Wis. Stats.), the municipality must return excess funds based on each taxing jurisdiction's portion of the total tax rate. DOR recommends basing the distribution on the most recent tax levy proportions without the tax increment. Column A of the Tax Increment Worksheet (PC-202) may be used for this calculation. Contact
lgs@wisconsin.gov
for further assistance.

Q: How long does the municipality have to return the excess funds?
A: State law does not provide a specific deadline for distributing excess funds to other taxing jurisdictions. However, the TID's final audit must be completed within one year of the termination resolution. DOR recommends distributing the excess funds when the final audit is completed.

Q: What if a municipality terminated a TID and has some outstanding expenses to pay before disbursing any extra funds to the other overlying tax jurisdictions?
A: It is the municipality's responsibility to determine proper administration in this situation. For example, a municipality may set up a temporary escrow account to cover the final expenses. This allows the municipality to complete its final audit.

Q: If a municipality adopts a TID termination resolution and notified DOR, can it rescind the termination resolution so it can adopt an affordable housing resolution?
A:
The answer depends on whether the termination deadline has passed and whether the TID has reached its maximum life. Municipalities must certify a TID as active or inactive by April 15 under state law (sec. 66.1105(6)(ae) Wis. Stats.). Both the termination and rescission must be in the same year based on this deadline. See the TID Termination Timeframes table.
Rescinding a termination resolution is possible when all items below apply:
Rescinding a termination resolution is not possible if any of the items below apply:
- TID has not reached its maximum life (or extended life) date
- Municipality paid the administrative fee for the year to keep the TID active. If the fee is paid, DOR considers the TID active.
- April 15 deadline has not passed; the TID number is still on the current year assessment/tax roll
- TID's maximum life (or extended life) date has passed
- Administrative fee deadline has passed and the fee was not paid. Since the fee was not paid, DOR considers this TID terminated.
- April 15 deadline has passed; the TID number is removed from the current year assessment/tax roll
The answer depends on whether the termination deadline has passed and whether the TID has reached its maximum life. Municipalities must certify a TID as active or inactive by April 15 under state law (sec.
66.1105(6)(ae)
Wis. Stats.). Both the termination and rescission must be in the same year based on this deadline. See the
TID Termination Timeframes
table.
Rescinding a termination resolution is possible when all items below apply:
TID has not reached its maximum life (or extended life) date
Municipality paid the administrative fee for the year to keep the TID active. If the fee is paid, DOR considers the TID active.
April 15 deadline has not passed; the TID number is still on the current year assessment/tax roll
Rescinding a termination resolution is not possible if any of the items below apply:
TID's maximum life (or extended life) date has passed
Administrative fee deadline has passed and the fee was not paid. Since the fee was not paid, DOR considers this TID terminated.
April 15 deadline has passed; the TID number is removed from the current year assessment/tax roll

Q: What happens to the TID's personal property aid and exempt computer aid when the TID terminates?
A:
Effective with the 2022 payments, based on 2021 Act 61 , when a TID receiving these aid payments terminates, DOR transfers the payments to the overlying jurisdictions (ex: municipality, county, school district, technical college).
Effective with the 2022 payments, based on
2021 Act 61
, when a TID receiving these aid payments terminates, DOR transfers the payments to the overlying jurisdictions (ex: municipality, county, school district, technical college).

Q: When does a municipality receive the one-time levy limit adjustment? How is this calculated?
A:
In the year after the TID's termination year (see TID Termination Timeframes ), a municipality may use a one-time levy limit increase. The levy limit adjustment appears on the Levy Limit Worksheet the same year as the TID's termination year. For example, for a TID with a 2026 termination year, the 2026 Levy Limit Worksheet for taxes payable in 2027 reflects the increase.
For TIDs created before 2025, the increase percentage equals the TID's final increment value divided by the municipal TID equalized value without the TID increment, multiplied by 50%. The final increment and municipal equalized value used in the calculation are from the last year the TID had an equalized value (the year before the termination year).
Note: If the municipality has more than one TID with the same termination year, the TID increment values are combined. A TID with a negative increment decreases the total increment used in the calculation.
For TIDs created in 2025 or after, the increase percentage equals 10% of the TID's new construction value divided by the municipal TID equalized value without the TID increment. An additional 15% of the TID's new construction value may be added if the TID terminates within 75% of the Joint Review Board's (JRB's) expected life.
Contact lgs@wisconsin.gov for more information.
In the year after the TID's termination year (see
TID Termination Timeframes
), a municipality may use a one-time levy limit increase. The levy limit adjustment appears on the Levy Limit Worksheet the same year as the TID's termination year. For example, for a TID with a 2026 termination year, the 2026 Levy Limit Worksheet for taxes payable in 2027 reflects the increase.
For TIDs created before 2025, the increase percentage equals the TID's final increment value divided by the municipal TID equalized value without the TID increment, multiplied by 50%. The final increment and municipal equalized value used in the calculation are from the last year the TID had an equalized value (the year before the termination year).
Note: If the municipality has more than one TID with the same termination year, the TID increment values are combined. A TID with a negative increment decreases the total increment used in the calculation.
For TIDs created in 2025 or after, the increase percentage equals 10% of the TID's new construction value divided by the municipal TID equalized value without the TID increment. An additional 15% of the TID's new construction value may be added if the TID terminates within 75% of the Joint Review Board's (JRB's) expected life.
Contact lgs@wisconsin.gov for more information.

Q: How many times can a municipality change the boundaries of a Tax Incremental District (TID)?
A: A municipality may complete a territory amendment to change TID boundaries up to four times during the TID's life. If a municipality completes a single amendment to add and subtract territory, it counts as one of the four territory amendments. Parcels within the TID must remain contiguous (geographically connected) when adding or subtracting parcels.

Q: How does a subtraction amendment differ from an addition amendment?
A:
Subtraction amendment – decreases the number of parcels in the TID
Addition amendment – increases the number of parcels in the TID
- Value of the removed parcels (at the time they were added to the TID) is subtracted from the base value
- Value of personal property assessed in the TID (at the time the parcels were added to the TID) is also subtracted from the base value. This is possible if both the situations below apply:
- The personal property became part of the TID prior to 2024 (which is the year personal property became tax exempt)
- The municipality has not requested DOR adjust the TID's base value due to personal property exemption
- The value of the additional parcels (in the amendment year) is added to the existing base value
Subtraction amendment –
decreases the number of parcels in the TID
Value of the removed parcels (at the time they were added to the TID) is subtracted from the base value
Value of personal property assessed in the TID (at the time the parcels were added to the TID) is also subtracted from the base value. This is possible if both the situations below apply:
The personal property became part of the TID prior to 2024 (which is the year personal property became tax exempt)
The municipality has not requested DOR adjust the TID's base value due to personal property exemption
Addition amendment –
increases the number of parcels in the TID
The value of the additional parcels (in the amendment year) is added to the existing base value

Q: Does all property in a boundary amendment have to be in the same area?
A: No. As long as added or subtracted parcels are contiguous with the original TID parcels, the added or subtracted parcels do not have to be in the same area.

Q: If a municipality adds territory to a TID, does the total area of the TID (original parcels and added parcels) have to meet the 50%  minimum property type based on its original TID type?
A:
Yes. After a TID is created and declared a specific type, it must remain that type throughout its life. If a municipality adds parcels, 50% of the total TID area must meet the TID's original type. If a municipality subtracts parcels, 50% of the remaining property must meet the TID's original type.
To calculate the percentage when adding parcels:
To calculate the percentage when subtracting parcels:
- New parcels added – use the current type designated
- Existing parcels – use the type designated for each parcel when the TID was created
- Recalculate the percentage of all parcels designated at the original TID type (blighted, industrial etc.). The percentage must be at least 50%.
- Subtract the acreage of the removed parcels originally designated as the specific TID type (blighted, industrial, etc.) from the original total acreage
- Recalculate the percentage of the remaining parcel acreage designated at that TID type. The percentage must be at least 50%.
Yes. After a TID is created and declared a specific type, it must remain that type throughout its life. If a municipality adds parcels, 50% of the total TID area must meet the TID's original type. If a municipality subtracts parcels, 50% of the remaining property must meet the TID's original type.
To calculate the percentage when adding parcels:

Existing parcels – use the type designated for each parcel when the TID was created
Recalculate the percentage of all parcels designated at the original TID type (blighted, industrial etc.). The percentage must be at least 50%.
To calculate the percentage when subtracting parcels:
Subtract the acreage of the removed parcels originally designated as the specific TID type (blighted, industrial, etc.) from the original total acreage
Recalculate the percentage of the remaining parcel acreage designated at that TID type. The percentage must be at least 50%.

Q: What should the map and the metes and bounds (boundary legal description) show in a Territory Amendment?
A:
Map – must show the full TID's boundary and identify the added or subtracted parcels. The new boundary must show that the entire TID remains contiguous. Review Parcels Common Question 4 for more information on map requirements.
Boundary legal description – must be revised to describe the updated TID outer boundary of the full TID, including the necessary revisions to account for parcel changes made in the amendment.
Map –
must show the full TID's boundary and identify the added or subtracted parcels. The new boundary must show that the entire TID remains contiguous. Review
Parcels Common Question 4
for more information on map requirements.
Boundary legal description –
must be revised to describe the updated TID outer boundary of the full TID, including the necessary revisions to account for parcel changes made in the amendment.

Q: Can a municipality discuss multiple amendments (to update projects, add/subtract territory, allocate to another TID) at the same public hearing?
A:
Yes. However, the municipality must describe each action in a separate statement in the public hearing notice.
See the sample Combined Public Hearing Notice and first JRB meeting – Amendment .
Yes. However, the municipality must describe each action in a separate statement in the public hearing notice.
See the sample
Combined Public Hearing Notice and first JRB meeting – Amendment
.

Q: Can a municipality complete a territory addition amendment and update the project plan with new projects at the same time?
A:
Yes. A municipality usually updates the project plan during a territory amendment to add projects in the new territory. The municipality can also update the project plan with projects that do not relate to the new territory.  In both cases, the municipality can complete and submit one set of forms to DOR.
See the TID Checklist for the required forms and documents.
Yes. A municipality usually updates the project plan during a territory amendment to add projects in the new territory. The municipality can also update the project plan with projects that do not relate to the new territory.  In both cases, the municipality can complete and submit one set of forms to DOR.
See the
TID Checklist
for the required forms and documents.

Q: When territory is added to a TID, does this change the base value of the existing parcels?
A:
No. The base value of the existing parcels does not change; however, when territory is added, the new parcels' current value is added to the TID's existing base value.
Example: TID 2 was created in 2021 with a base value of $150,000. In 2025, the municipality adds 10 parcels valued (as of January 1, 2025) at $45,000. The $150,000 existing base value plus the $45,000 value of additional parcels equals $195,000. In 2026, the TID's new base value is $195,000.
No. The base value of the existing parcels does not change; however, when territory is added, the new parcels' current value is added to the TID's existing base value.
Example:
TID 2 was created in 2021 with a base value of $150,000. In 2025, the municipality adds 10 parcels valued (as of January 1, 2025) at $45,000. The $150,000 existing base value plus the $45,000 value of additional parcels equals $195,000. In 2026, the TID's new base value is $195,000.

Q: Does adding territory affect the TID expenditure period?
A: No. Adding territory does not change the TID's expenditure period. All project costs (original and additional costs) must be incurred within five years before the TID's maximum life.

Q: Does a municipality need to notify owners of blighted property prior to an amendment hearing?
A: Yes. When adding parcels to a blighted or rehabilitation/conservation TID, the municipality must notify the owners of parcels being added and identified as blighted or rehabilitation/conservation 15 days before the public hearing.

Q: Can a municipality amend the boundaries of a distressed or severely distressed TID?
A: A municipality may complete a boundary amendment to subtract territory from an existing distressed or severely distressed TID; however, a municipality may not add territory to a distressed or severely distressed TID.

Q: If the municipality adds territory to an existing TID, does the TID include the new territory's personal property and personal property value in the base?
A: No, personal property is exempt effective January 1, 2024. When amending a TID in 2024 or after, only the taxable real property added to the TID becomes part of the TID's new base value.

Q: If a municipality is over the 12% value limit, can the municipality add and subtract territory simultaneously?
A:
If a municipality is over the 12% value limit, it can add and subtract territory in the same TID at the same time as long as the net change to the base value is negative. However, the value of the added and subtracted parcels is determined differently.
Value of the:
See Value Limit Common Question 9 for additional information.
- Subtracted parcels – is the original value when the parcels entered the TID
- Additional parcels – is the value as of January 1 of the amendment year

Value of the:

Additional parcels – is the value as of January 1 of the amendment year

Q: A municipality is subtracting a parcel that did not exist when the TID was created. The parcel being subtracted was a portion of a larger parcel that was divided after the TID was created. How is the base value of the parcel being subtracted determined?
A:
When the parcel was part of one larger original TID parcel, the assessor must determine the prorated value of the parcel at the time it was included in the TID. For the land value, generally, this is based on the percentage of the current parcel to the original parcel. For the building/improvements value (if any), it may depend on whether they were located on the portion being removed. Provide an explanation of how the assessor determined the values on the TID Territory Subtraction Workbook .
When the parcel was part of one larger original TID parcel, the assessor must determine the prorated value of the parcel at the time it was included in the TID. For the land value, generally, this is based on the percentage of the current parcel to the original parcel. For the building/improvements value (if any), it may depend on whether they were located on the portion being removed. Provide an explanation of how the assessor determined the values on the
TID Territory Subtraction Workbook
.

Q: Are the procedures (ex: notices, public hearings, resolutions) for creating a town TID under state law (sec. 60.23, Wis. Stats.), different from those for a city or village?
A:
No. The procedures are the same because the town chose to exercise all powers of a city, under sec. 66.1105, Wis. Stats. See the TID Checklist .
No. The procedures are the same because the town chose to exercise all powers of a city, under sec. 66.1105, Wis. Stats. See the
TID Checklist
.

Q: What additional requirements must a town meet compared to a city or village when creating a TID under sec. 60.23, Wis. Stats.?
A:
There are three additional requirements:
Note:
- Prior year equalized value — must be at least $500 million​
- Prior year population — must be at least 3,500 based on the Wisconsin Department of Administration's most recent Annual Population Estimates
- Sewer service — is or will be provided before use or operation of any improvements
- The prior year is the year before the town board adopts the creation resolution
- The project plan should show that the town meets these requirements

The prior year is the year before the town board adopts the creation resolution

Q: State law (sec. 60.23(32)(f)2. , Wis. Stats.) requires the town to select option (a), (b) or (c). What impact do these three options have on the project plan?
A:
Option (a) — (sec. 60.23(32)(f)2.a. )
Option (b) — (sec. 60.23(32)(f)2.b. )
Option (c) — (sec 60.23(32)(f)2.c. )
- At least 51% of the public infrastructure improvement value must be financed by a private developer or entity
- Development agreement is required to receive cash grants which will solely repay the developer or entity for public infrastructure costs
- Town expects all project costs to be paid within 90% of the TID's remaining life
- Expenditures may be made only within the first half of the TID's remaining life
- Joint Review Board can approve additional expenditures; however, the vote must be unanimous, and the expenditures cannot exceed the original expenditure period

Q: Is debt service included in the timeframe for Option (b) or Option (c)?
A:
Option (b) — the creation project plan must demonstrate the TID will have sufficient revenue to pay off debt and all project costs within 90% of the TID's maximum life. After all project costs are paid, the town must terminate the TID.
Option (c) — the municipality may only take on project costs within the first half of the TID's remaining life. Debt payments may continue through the TID's maximum life.

Option (c) —
the municipality may only take on project costs within the first half of the TID's remaining life. Debt payments may continue through the TID's maximum life.

Q: Does a town have to choose option (a), (b) or (c) each time it amends a TID, or do the options only apply when creating a TID?
A: A town must select an option (a, b, or c) when creating the TID, and document the selection in the project plan.  If the town completes an amendment, it must reconfirm the TID's original creation option or select a different option.

Q: What limit percentage affects a town?
A:
12% — if the TID is created under sec. 60.23, Wis. Stats., the 12% limit is used because the town chose to exercise all powers of a city under sec. 66.1105, Wis. Stats.
5% or 7% — if the TID is created under sec. 60.85, Wis. Stats., the 5% or 7% limit is used
See the Value Limit Common Questions for more information.
12% —
if the TID is created under sec. 60.23, Wis. Stats., the 12% limit is used because the town chose to exercise all powers of a city under sec. 66.1105, Wis. Stats.
5% or 7% —
if the TID is created under sec. 60.85, Wis. Stats., the 5% or 7% limit is used
See the
Value Limit Common Questions
for more information.

Q: Can a town TID still be created under sec. 60.85, Wis. Stats.?
A:
Yes. A town may create a TID under sec. 60.85, Wis. Stats. For more information, review the Town Creation web page.
Yes. A town may create a TID under sec. 60.85, Wis. Stats. For more information, review the
Town Creation
web page.

Q: What is the equalized value limit?
A:
The equalized value limit is the maximum property value a municipality can have within Tax Incremental Districts (TIDs). It is calculated by adding the equalized value of the new TID's taxable property as of January 1 (of the creation or amendment year) and the value increment of all existing TIDs for that municipality (as of the municipal resolution date). This value cannot exceed 12% of the municipality's total equalized value (as of the municipal resolution date).
See state law (sec. 66.1105(4)(gm)4.c. , Wis. Stats.).
The equalized value limit is the maximum property value a municipality can have within Tax Incremental Districts (TIDs). It is calculated by adding the equalized value of the new TID's taxable property as of January 1 (of the creation or amendment year) and the value increment of all existing TIDs for that municipality (as of the municipal resolution date). This value cannot exceed 12% of the municipality's total equalized value (as of the municipal resolution date).
See state law (sec.
66.1105(4)(gm)4.c.
, Wis. Stats.).

Q: What role do final equalized values (posted on August 15) have when calculating the 12% limit?
A:
The Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) updates municipal equalized values annually on August 15. The municipal TID creation (or amendment) resolution adoption date determines which year's increment value and municipal value to use in the value limit calculation. If the local legislative body resolution is adopted:
Review the TIF Value Limitation Report to view increment value, municipal value, and the percentage calculation by year.
- Before August 15 — use previous year's equalized value increment and municipal value
- On or after August 15 — use current year's equalized value increment and municipal value

Q: If a Tax Incremental District (TID) has parcels in more than one county, is the value limit calculation separated by county?
A: No. The entire TID's full value is included in the value limit calculation. Values from both counties for the TID base, TID increment and municipal equalized value are combined when calculating the 12% limit.

Q: When calculating the 12% limit for creating a TID or adding parcels to an existing TID, does the municipality include the increment for a terminated district?
A: No. The municipality does not include the terminated TID's increment value when calculating the 12% limit, as long as the municipality adopted the termination resolution before the creation or territory resolution.

Q: Are overlapped parcel values included in the 12% limit calculation?
A:
No. Under state law (sec. 66.1105(10)(c) , Wis. Stats.), the value of overlapped parcels are not included in the 12% limit calculation. The overlapped parcel values are already included in the increment for the existing TID.
No. Under state law (sec.
66.1105(10)(c)
, Wis. Stats.), the value of overlapped parcels are not included in the 12% limit calculation. The overlapped parcel values are already included in the increment for the existing TID.

Q: Can a municipality create a new TID with a zero base value if the municipality's existing TIDs already exceed the 12% limit?
A:
No. Under state law (sec. 66.1105(4)(gm)4.c. , Wis. Stats.), a new TID or territory addition cannot be approved if the municipality already exceeds the 12% limit. A new TID cannot be created even if the new TID completely overlaps an existing TID.
No. Under state law (sec.
66.1105(4)(gm)4.c.
, Wis. Stats.), a new TID or territory addition cannot be approved if the municipality already exceeds the 12% limit. A new TID cannot be created even if the new TID completely overlaps an existing TID.

Q: If a municipality is creating multiple TIDs in the same year, and all the TIDs are under 12% individually but collectively exceed the limit, can the TIDs be created?
A:
Yes. Each submission stands alone. As long as each TID (created/amended) in the same year meets the 12% limit individually, the TIDs can be created/amended. See state law (sec. 66.1105(4)(gm)4.c. , Wis. Stats.).
Yes. Each submission stands alone. As long as each TID (created/amended) in the same year meets the 12% limit individually, the TIDs can be created/amended. See state law (sec.
66.1105(4)(gm)4.c.
, Wis. Stats.).

Q: Does the 12% limit apply to territory amendments (adding/subtracting parcels), or does it only apply when a municipality is creating a new Tax Incremental District (TID)?
A: The 12% limit applies to new TID creations (except designated Environmental Remediation (ER) TIDs) and TID amendments adding parcels. The value limit calculation is part of the required findings in the municipal resolution. The 12% value limit does not apply when a municipality is subtracting parcels from a TID.

Q: When a municipality amends an existing TID to add parcels, how is the 12% limit calculated?
A: The equalized value of the added parcels only (as of January 1 of the amendment year) plus the value increment of all existing TIDs (as of the municipal resolution date), divided by the municipal equalized value (as of the municipal resolution date) equals the limit percentage. This limit cannot exceed 12%​.

Q: When a municipality amends an existing TID to add and subtract parcels, how does the 12% limit apply?
A:
If a municipality completes an amendment that adds and subtracts parcels at the same time, the base value of the added and the subtracted parcels are combined. The resulting value is used in the value limit calculation. Subtracted parcels use the value from the year they entered the TID. Added parcels use the value as of January 1 of the amendment year.
Example 1: A municipality adds one parcel with a value of $100,000 and subtracts one parcel that had a value of $50,000 when it entered the TID. The combined value is an addition of $50,000. The $50,000 total is used in the 12% value limit calculation.
Example 2: A municipality adds one parcel with a value of $50,000 and subtracts one parcel that had a value of $100,000 when it entered the TID. Because the combined value is a subtraction of $50,000, the amendment is not required to meet the 12% value limit.
If a municipality completes an amendment that adds and subtracts parcels at the same time, the base value of the added and the subtracted parcels are combined. The resulting value is used in the value limit calculation. Subtracted parcels use the value from the year they entered the TID. Added parcels use the value as of January 1 of the amendment year.
Example 1:
A municipality adds one parcel with a value of $100,000 and subtracts one parcel that had a value of $50,000 when it entered the TID. The combined value is an addition of $50,000. The $50,000 total is used in the 12% value limit calculation.
Example 2:
A municipality adds one parcel with a value of $50,000 and subtracts one parcel that had a value of $100,000 when it entered the TID. Because the combined value is a subtraction of $50,000, the amendment is not required to meet the 12% value limit.

Q: Can a municipality amend a project plan to add projects when the municipality is over the 12% limit?
A: Yes. A municipality can amend the project plan to add projects when the municipality is over the 12% limit. The 12% limit only applies when a TID is created or parcels are added.

Q: When a municipality amends a TID using simultaneous creation and subtraction, how does the 12% limit apply?
A:
Under state law (sec. 66.1105(17) , Wis. Stats.), a municipality may complete a simultaneous creation and subtraction amendment without including the 12% finding in the resolution. The municipality must submit the creation and subtraction amendment together and include a fair market value appraisal for each. The appraisals must show that the property value being removed in the subtraction amendment equals or exceeds the amount needed for the proposed TID to comply with the 12% limit.
A municipality may only complete a simultaneous creation and subtraction if it has no other active TID created using this option.
Under state law (sec.
66.1105(17)

simultaneous creation and subtraction
amendment without including the 12% finding in the resolution. The municipality must submit the creation and subtraction amendment together and include a fair market value appraisal for each. The appraisals must show that the property value being removed in the subtraction amendment equals or exceeds the amount needed for the proposed TID to comply with the 12% limit.
A municipality may only complete a simultaneous creation and subtraction if it has no other active TID created using this option.

Q: Does the 12% value limit apply to Town TIDs created under state law (sec. 60.85 , Wis. Stats.)?
A:
No. Under state law (sec. 60.85(3)(h)5.d. , Wis. Stats.), the limits are different. A town can only create a TID if it meets the 5% or 7% limit:
5% limit — the district's equalized value plus the value increment of all existing districts in the town cannot exceed 5% of the town's total equalized value
7% limit — the district's equalized value plus the current equalized value of all existing districts in the town cannot exceed 7% of the town's total equalized value

, Wis. Stats.), the limits are different. A town can only create a TID if it meets the 5% or 7% limit:

the district's equalized value plus the
value increment
of all existing districts in the town cannot exceed 5% of the town's total equalized value
7% limit —
the district's equalized value plus the
current equalized value
of all existing districts in the town cannot exceed 7% of the town's total equalized value

Q: Does the 12% limit apply to Environmental Remediation (ER) TIDs created under state law (sec. 66.1105 , Wis. Stats.)?
A:
Yes. However, the municipality can designate one ER TID created under sec. 66.1105 , Wis. Stats., as excluded from the 12% limit.
The municipality cannot change this designation to another ER TID. After the designated ER TID terminates, the municipality may designate another ER TID created under sec. 66.1105 , Wis. Stats., as excluded from the value limit.

, Wis. Stats., as excluded from the 12% limit.
The municipality cannot change this designation to another ER TID. After the designated ER TID terminates, the municipality may designate another ER TID created under sec.
66.1105
, Wis. Stats., as excluded from the value limit.
